The Mysterious Affair at [Styles]4-styles

by [Agatha Christie]29-agatha christie

CHAPTER I. [I]0-i GO TO [STYLES]30-styles

The intense interest aroused in the public by what was known at the time as " The Styles Case "[130-the family] has now somewhat subsided . Nevertheless , in view of the world - wide notoriety which attended it , [I]0-i have been asked , both by [[my]0-i friend]129-my friend [Poirot]31-poirot and [the family]130-the family [themselves]130-the family , to write an account of the whole story . This , [we]131-we trust , will effectually silence the sensational rumours which still persist .

[I]0-i will therefore briefly set down the circumstances which led to [my]0-i being connected with the affair .

[I]0-i had been invalided [home]132-home from [the Front]2-the front ; and , after spending some months in [a rather depressing Convalescent Home]133-a rather depressing convalescent home , was given a month 's sick leave . Having [no near relations]134-no near relations or [friends]135-friends , [I]0-i was trying to make up [my]0-i mind what to do , when [I]0-i ran across [John Cavendish]32-john . [I]0-i had seen very little of [him]32-john for some years . Indeed , [I]0-i had never known [him]32-john particularly well . [He]32-john was a good fifteen years [my]0-i senior , for one thing , though [he]32-john hardly looked [his]32-john forty - five years . As [a boy]136-a boy , though , [I]0-i had often stayed at [Styles]4-styles , [[[his]32-john mother]137-his mother 's place in [Essex]3-essex]138-his mother 's place in essex .

[We]139-we had a good yarn about old times , and it ended in [his]32-john inviting [me]0-i down to [Styles]4-styles to spend [my]0-i leave [there]140-there .

" [The mater]1017-the mater will be delighted to see [you]0-i again after all those years , "[32-john] [he]32-john added .

" [[Your]0-i mother]1018-your mother keeps well ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" Oh , yes . [I]32-john suppose [you]0-i know that [she]1018-your mother has married again ? "[32-john]

[I]0-i am afraid [I]0-i showed [my]0-i surprise rather plainly . [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish , who had married [[John]32-john 's father]141-john 's father when [he]141-john 's father was [a widower]142-a widower with [two sons]143-two sons , had been [a handsome woman of middle - age]144-a handsome woman of middle - age as [I]0-i remembered [her]33-mrs. cavendish . [She]33-mrs. cavendish certainly could not be a day less than seventy now . [I]0-i recalled [her]33-mrs. cavendish as an energetic , autocratic personality , somewhat inclined to charitable and social notoriety , with a fondness for opening bazaars and playing [the Lady Bountiful]145-the lady bountiful . [She]33-mrs. cavendish was [a most generous woman]146-a most generous woman , and possessed a considerable fortune of [her]33-mrs. cavendish own .

[[Their]147-their country - place]148-their country - place , [Styles Court]5-styles court , had been purchased by [Mr. Cavendish]32-john early in [their]147-their married life . [He]141-john 's father had been completely under [[his]141-john 's father wife]149-his wife 's ascendancy , so much so that , on dying , [he]141-john 's father left [the place]150-the place to [her]149-his wife for [her]149-his wife lifetime , as well as the larger part of [his]141-john 's father income ; an arrangement that was distinctly unfair to [[his]141-john 's father two sons]151-his two sons . [[Their]147-their step - mother]152-their step - mother , however , had always been most generous to [them]147-their ; indeed , [they]147-their were so young at the time of [[their]147-their father]153-their father 's remarriage that [they]147-their always thought of [her]152-their step - mother as [[their]147-their own mother]154-their own mother .

[Lawrence]34-monsieur lawrence , [the younger]155-the younger , had been [a delicate youth]156-a delicate youth . [He]34-monsieur lawrence had qualified as [a doctor]157-a doctor but early relinquished the profession of medicine , and lived at [home]132-home while pursuing literary ambitions ; though [his]34-monsieur lawrence verses never had any marked success .

[John]32-john practised for some time as [a barrister]159-a barrister , but had finally settled down to the more congenial life of [a country squire]160-a country squire . [He]32-john had married two years ago , and had taken [[his]32-john wife]149-his wife to live at [Styles]4-styles , though [I]0-i entertained a shrewd suspicion that [he]32-john would have preferred [[his]32-john mother]137-his mother to increase [his]32-john allowance , which would have enabled [him]32-john to have [a home of [his]32-john own]163-a home of his own . [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish , however , was [a lady who liked to make [her]33-mrs. cavendish own plans]164-a lady who liked to make her own plans , and expected [other people]165-other people to fall in with [them]166-them , and in this case [she]33-mrs. cavendish certainly had the whip hand , namely : the purse strings .

[John]32-john noticed [my]0-i surprise at the news of [[his]32-john mother]137-his mother 's remarriage and smiled rather ruefully .

" [Rotten little bounder]1019-rotten little bounder too ! "[32-john] [he]32-john said savagely . " [I]32-john can tell [you]0-i , [Hastings]35-hastings , it 's making life jolly difficult for [us]1020-us . As for [Evie]36-evelyn howard [you]0-i remember [Evie]36-evelyn howard ? "[32-john]

" [You]0-i were going to say ? "[33-mrs. cavendish]

" Oh , [this fellow]1026-this fellow ! "[32-john]

[I]0-i nodded .

" Well , of course the war has turned [the hundreds into thousands]1034-the hundreds into thousands . No doubt [the fellow]1028-the fellow was very useful to [her]1017-the mater . "[0-i]

" Difficult ! It 's damnable ! "[0-i]

[John Cavendish]32-john was waiting on [the platform]173-the platform , and piloted [me]0-i out to [the car]174-the car .

" Got a drop or two of petrol still , [you]0-i see , "[32-john] [he]32-john remarked . " Mainly owing to [the mater]1017-the mater 's activities . "[32-john]

[The village of [Styles St. Mary]6-styles st. mary]175-the village of styles st. mary was situated about two miles from [the little station]176-the little station , and [Styles Court]5-styles court lay a mile the other side of [it]175-the village of styles st. mary . It was a still , warm day in early July . As [one]177-one looked out over [the flat Essex country]178-the flat essex country , lying so green and peaceful under the afternoon sun , it seemed almost impossible to believe that , not so very far away , a great war was running its appointed course . [I]0-i felt [I]0-i had suddenly strayed into [another world]179-another world . As [we]180-we turned in at [the lodge]181-the lodge gates , [John]32-john said :

" [I]32-john 'm afraid [you]0-i 'll find it very quiet down here , [Hastings]35-hastings . "[32-john]

" [[My]32-john dear fellow]1041-my dear fellow , that 's just what [I]32-john want . "[32-john]

" Oh , it 's pleasant enough if [you]0-i want to lead the idle life . [I]32-john drill with [the volunteers]1042-the volunteers twice a week , and lend a hand at [the farms]1043-the farms . [[My]32-john wife]1044-my wife works regularly on [the land]1045-the land ' . [She]1044-my wife is up at five every morning to milk , and keeps at [it]1046-it steadily until lunchtime . It 's a jolly good life taking it all round if it were n't for that fellow [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp ! "[32-john] [He]32-john checked [the car]174-the car suddenly , and glanced at [his]32-john watch . " [I]32-john wonder if [we]1047-we 've time to pick up [Cynthia]38-cynthia . A figure rose from one of the basket chairs , and came a few steps to meet [us]189-us .

" [[My]32-john wife]1044-my wife , [Hastings]40-miss howard , "[32-john] said [John]32-john .

[I]0-i shall never forget [my]0-i first sight of [Mary Cavendish]41-mary . [I]0-i shall never forget them .

[She]41-mary greeted [me]0-i with a few words of pleasant welcome in a low clear voice , and [I]0-i sank into a basket chair feeling distinctly glad that [I]0-i had accepted [John]32-john 's invitation . [I]0-i looked with some curiosity at " [Alfred]37-mr. inglethorp darling "[0-i] . [He]196-a man certainly struck a rather alien note . With the presence of [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp , a sense of constraint and veiled hostility seemed to settle down upon [the company]202-the company . [Miss Howard]40-miss howard , in particular , took no pains to conceal [her]149-his wife feelings . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp , however , seemed to notice nothing unusual . [Her]44-mrs. inglethorp volubility , which [I]0-i remembered of old , had lost nothing in the intervening years , and [she]44-mrs. inglethorp poured out a steady flood of conversation , mainly on the subject of the forthcoming bazaar which [she]44-mrs. inglethorp was organizing and which was to take place shortly . Occasionally [she]44-mrs. inglethorp referred to [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband over a question of days or dates . [His]32-john watchful and attentive manner never varied . [Presently Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp turned to give some instructions about letters to [Evelyn Howard]36-evelyn howard , and [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband addressed [me]0-i in [his]203-her husband painstaking voice :

" No , before the war [I]203-her husband was in [Lloyd 's]9-lloyd 's . "[203-her husband]

" Perhaps . Either that or a fresh start altogether . "[203-her husband]

CHAPTER II . THE 16TH AND 17TH OF JULY

[I]0-i had arrived at [Styles]4-styles on the 5th of July . [I]0-i come now to the events of the 16th and 17th of that month . For the convenience of [the reader]250-the reader [I]0-i will recapitulate the incidents of those days in as exact a manner as possible . They were elicited subsequently at the trial by a process of long and tedious cross - examinations .

[I]0-i received a letter from [Evelyn Howard]36-evelyn howard a couple of days after [her]36-evelyn howard departure , telling [me]0-i [she]36-evelyn howard was working as [a nurse at [the big hospital in [Middlingham]14-middlingham]252-the big hospital in middlingham]251-a nurse at the big hospital in middlingham , [a manufacturing town some fifteen miles away]253-a manufacturing town some fifteen miles away , and begging [me]0-i to let [her]36-evelyn howard know if [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp should show any wish to be reconciled .

The only fly in the ointment of [my]0-i peaceful days was [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish 's extraordinary , and , for [my]0-i part , unaccountable preference for [the society of [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein]254-the society of dr. bauerstein . What [she]44-mrs. inglethorp saw in [the man]1112-the man [I]0-i can not imagine , but [she]44-mrs. inglethorp was always asking [him]1112-the man up to [the house]1063-the house , and often went off for long expeditions with [him]1112-the man . [I]0-i must confess that [I]0-i was quite unable to see [his]1112-the man attraction .

The 16th of July fell on a Monday . It was a day of turmoil . The famous bazaar had taken place on Saturday , and an entertainment , in connection with the same charity , at which [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp was to recite a War poem , was to be held that night . [We]257-we were all busy during the morning arranging and decorating [the Hall in [the village]1124-the village where it was to take place]258-the hall in the village where it was to take place . [We]257-we had a late luncheon and spent the afternoon resting in [the garden]260-the garden . [I]0-i noticed that [John]32-john 's manner was somewhat unusual . [He]32-john seemed very excited and restless .

After tea , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp went to lie down to rest before [her]44-mrs. inglethorp efforts in the evening and [I]0-i challenged [Mary Cavendish]41-mary to a single at tennis .

About a quarter to seven , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp called [us]257-we that [we]257-we should be late as supper was early that night . [We]257-we had rather a scramble to get ready in time ; and before the meal was over the motor was waiting at the door .

The entertainment was a great success , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's recitation receiving tremendous applause . There were also some tableaux in which [Cynthia]48-cynthia took part . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp did not return with [us]257-we , having been asked to a supper party , and to remain the night with [some friends who had been acting with [her]44-mrs. inglethorp in the tableaux]261-some friends who had been acting with her in the tableaux .

The following morning , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp stayed in bed to breakfast , as [she]44-mrs. inglethorp was rather overtired ; but [she]44-mrs. inglethorp appeared in [her]44-mrs. inglethorp briskest mood about 12.30 , and swept [Lawrence]52-lawrence and [myself]0-i off to a luncheon party .

" Such a charming invitation from [Mrs. Rolleston]57-mrs. rolleston . [[Lady Tadminster]42-lady tadminster 's sister]1141-lady tadminster 's sister , [you]0-i know . [The Rollestons]58-the rollestons came over with [the Conqueror one of [[our]257-we oldest families]1143-our oldest families]1142-the conqueror one of our oldest families . "[44-mrs. inglethorp]

[Mary]41-mary had excused [herself]41-mary on the plea of an engagement with [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein .

[We]257-we had a pleasant luncheon , and as [we]257-we drove away [Lawrence]52-lawrence suggested that [we]257-we should return by [Tadminster]8-tadminster , which was barely a mile out of [our]257-we way , and pay a visit to [Cynthia]48-cynthia in [[her]48-cynthia dispensary]262-her dispensary . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp replied that this was an excellent idea , but as [she]44-mrs. inglethorp had several letters to write [she]44-mrs. inglethorp would drop [us]257-we [there]140-there , and [we]257-we could come back with [Cynthia]48-cynthia in the pony - trap .

[We]257-we were detained under suspicion by [the hospital porter]264-the hospital porter , until [Cynthia]48-cynthia appeared to vouch for [us]257-we , looking very cool and sweet in [her]48-cynthia long white overall . "[48-cynthia]

" Say something original , "[48-cynthia] groaned [Cynthia]48-cynthia . " [Every single person who comes up here]1145-every single person who comes up here says that . [I]0-i pleaded guilty with a laugh .

" If [[you]48-cynthia people]1148-you people only knew how fatally easy it is to poison [someone]1149-someone by mistake , [you]48-cynthia would n't joke about it . Come on , let 's have tea . [We]268-we had a very cheery tea , and assisted [Cynthia]48-cynthia to wash up afterwards . [We]268-we had just put away the last tea - spoon when a knock came at the door . The countenances of [Cynthia]48-cynthia and [Nibs]59-nibs were suddenly petrified into a stern and forbidding expression .

[I]0-i had seen [Lawrence]52-lawrence in quite a different light that afternoon . [Poirot]31-poirot was [an extraordinary looking little man]286-an extraordinary looking little man . [He]31-poirot was hardly more than five feet , four inches , but carried [himself]31-poirot with great dignity . [His]31-poirot head was exactly the shape of an egg , and [he]31-poirot always perched it a little on one side . [His]31-poirot moustache was very stiff and military . CHAPTER III . THE NIGHT OF THE TRAGEDY

To make this part of [my]0-i story clear , [I]0-i append the following plan of [the first floor of [Styles]4-styles]330-the first floor of styles . [[The servants]331-the servants ' rooms]332-the servants ' rooms are reached through the door B. [They]332-the servants ' rooms have no communication with the right wing , where [[the Inglethorps]55-the inglethorps ' rooms]333-the inglethorps ' rooms were situated .

[ Illustration ]

It seemed to be the middle of the night when [I]0-i was awakened by [Lawrence Cavendish]52-lawrence . [He]52-lawrence had a candle in [his]52-lawrence hand , and the agitation of [his]52-lawrence face told [me]0-i at once that something was seriously wrong .

" What 's the matter ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , sitting up in bed , and trying to collect [my]0-i scattered thoughts .

" [We]1181-we are afraid [[my]0-i mother]1050-my mother is very ill . [She]1050-my mother seems to be having some kind of fit . Unfortunately [she]1050-my mother has locked [herself]1050-my mother in . "[0-i]

" [I]0-i 'll come at once . "[0-i]

[I]0-i sprang out of bed ; and , pulling on a dressing - gown , followed [Lawrence]52-lawrence along [the passage]334-the passage and [the gallery]335-the gallery to [the right wing of [the house]1063-the house]336-the right wing of the house .

[John Cavendish]32-john joined [us]338-us , and [one or two of [the servants]331-the servants]339-one or two of the servants were standing round in a state of awe - stricken excitement . [Lawrence]52-lawrence turned to [[his]52-lawrence brother]277-his brother .

" What do [you]277-his brother think [we]338-us had better do ? "[52-lawrence]

Never , [I]0-i thought , had [his]52-lawrence indecision of character been more apparent .

[John]32-john rattled the handle of [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's door violently , but with no effect . It was obviously locked or bolted on the inside . [The whole household]342-the whole household was aroused by now . The most alarming sounds were audible from the interior of [the room]230-the room . Clearly something must be done .

" Try going through [[Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp 's room]1183-mr. inglethorp 's room , [sir]1184-sir , "[64-dorcas] cried [Dorcas]64-dorcas . " Oh , [the poor mistress]1185-the poor mistress ! "[64-dorcas]

Suddenly [I]0-i realized that [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp was not with [us]344-we that [he]37-mr. inglethorp alone had given no sign of [his]37-mr. inglethorp presence . [John]32-john opened the door of [[his]32-john room]345-his room . It was pitch dark , but [Lawrence]52-lawrence was following with the candle , and by its feeble light [we]344-we saw that the bed had not been slept in , and that there was no sign of [the room]230-the room having been occupied .

[We]344-we went straight to the connecting door . That , too , was locked or bolted on the inside . What was to be done ?

" Oh , dear , [sir]1184-sir , "[64-dorcas] cried [Dorcas]64-dorcas , wringing [her]64-dorcas hands , " what ever shall [we]344-we do ? "[64-dorcas]

" [We]344-we must try and break the door in , [I]41-mary suppose . It 'll be a tough job , though . [He]347-he ran rapidly down [the corridor]348-the corridor to [[Cynthia]62-miss cynthia 's room]349-cynthia 's room . [We]352-we strained and heaved together . The framework of the door was solid , and for a long time it resisted [our]352-we efforts , but at last [we]352-we felt it give beneath [our]352-we weight , and finally , with a resounding crash , it was burst open .

[We]352-we stumbled in together , [Lawrence]52-lawrence still holding [his]52-lawrence candle . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp was lying on the bed , [her]44-mrs. inglethorp whole form agitated by violent convulsions , in one of which [she]44-mrs. inglethorp must have overturned the table beside [her]44-mrs. inglethorp . [John]32-john strode across [the room]230-the room , and lit the gas . The still feebly flickering ashes in the grate , and the row of prim ornaments on the mantelpiece , were surely harmless enough .

The violence of [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's attack seemed to be passing . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp was able to speak in short gasps .

" Better now very sudden stupid of [me]44-mrs. inglethorp to lock [myself]44-mrs. inglethorp in . "[44-mrs. inglethorp]

" [Alfred Alfred]1192-alfred alfred "[44-mrs. inglethorp] Then [she]44-mrs. inglethorp fell back motionless on the pillows .

[I]0-i had been turning over an idea in [my]0-i head , and [I]0-i felt that the moment had now come to broach it . Yet [I]0-i was a little chary of doing so . CHAPTER IV . POIROT INVESTIGATES

[The house which [the Belgians]69-the belgians occupied in [the village]1124-the village]395-the house which the belgians occupied in the village was quite close to [the park]214-the park gates . [One]177-one could save time by taking [a narrow path through the long grass , which cut off the detours of [the winding drive]400-the winding drive]399-a narrow path through the long grass , which cut off the detours of the winding drive . So [I]0-i , accordingly , went that way . [I]0-i had nearly reached [the lodge]181-the lodge , when [my]0-i attention was arrested by the running figure of [a man approaching [me]0-i]402-a man approaching me . It was [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . Where had [he]37-mr. inglethorp been ? How did [he]37-mr. inglethorp intend to explain [his]37-mr. inglethorp absence ?

[He]37-mr. inglethorp accosted [me]0-i eagerly .

" [[My]402-a man approaching me God]1206-my god ! This is terrible ! [[My]402-a man approaching me poor wife]1207-my poor wife ! [I]402-a man approaching me have only just heard . "[402-a man approaching me]

" Where have [you]37-mr. inglethorp been ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" [Denby]70-denby kept [me]402-a man approaching me late last night . It was one o'clock before [we]1208-we 'd finished . Then [I]402-a man approaching me found that [I]402-a man approaching me 'd forgotten the latch - key after all . [I]402-a man approaching me did n't want to arouse [the household]1209-the household , so [Denby]70-denby gave [me]402-a man approaching me a bed . "[402-a man approaching me]

" How did [you]37-mr. inglethorp hear the news ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" [Wilkins]66-dr. wilkins knocked [Denby]70-denby up to tell [him]37-mr. inglethorp . [[My]1112-the man poor [Emily]50-aunt emily]1210-my poor emily ! [She]50-aunt emily was so self - sacrificing such a noble character . [She]50-aunt emily over - taxed [her]50-aunt emily strength . "[1112-the man]

A wave of revulsion swept over [me]0-i . What [a consummate hypocrite]403-a consummate hypocrite [the man]1112-the man was !

" [I]0-i must hurry on , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , thankful that [he]1112-the man did not ask [me]0-i whither [I]0-i was bound .

In a few minutes [I]0-i was knocking at the door of [Leastways Cottage]405-leastways cottage .

Getting no answer , [I]0-i repeated [my]0-i summons impatiently . A window above [me]0-i was cautiously opened , and [Poirot]63-poirot [himself]63-poirot looked out .

[He]63-poirot gave an exclamation of surprise at seeing [me]0-i . In a few brief words , [I]0-i explained the tragedy that had occurred , and that [I]0-i wanted [his]1112-the man help .

" Wait , [[my]1112-the man friend]129-my friend , [I]1112-the man will let [you]129-my friend in , and [you]129-my friend shall recount to [me]1112-the man the affair whilst [I]1112-the man dress . "[1112-the man]

In a few moments [he]1112-the man had unbarred the door , and [I]0-i followed [him]1112-the man up to [[his]1112-the man room]345-his room . There [he]1112-the man installed [me]0-i in a chair , and [I]0-i related the whole story , keeping back nothing , and omitting no circumstance , however insignificant , whilst [he]1112-the man [himself]1112-the man made a careful and deliberate toilet .

[I]0-i told [him]1112-the man of [my]0-i awakening , of [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's dying words , of [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband 's absence , of the quarrel the day before , of the scrap of conversation between [Mary]41-mary and [[her]41-mary mother - in - law]408-her mother - in - law that [I]0-i had overheard , of the former quarrel between [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp and [Evelyn Howard]36-evelyn howard , and of [the latter]320-the latter 's innuendoes .

[I]0-i was hardly as clear as [I]0-i could wish . [I]0-i repeated [myself]0-i several times , and occasionally had to go back to some detail that [I]0-i had forgotten . [Poirot]63-poirot smiled kindly on [me]0-i .

" The mind is confused ? Is it not so ? Take time , _ mon ami _ . [You]0-i are agitated ; [you]0-i are excited it is but natural . Presently , when [we]1212-we are calmer , [we]1212-we will arrange the facts , neatly , each in [his]63-poirot proper place . [We]1212-we will examine and reject . Those of importance [we]1212-we will put on one side ; those of no importance , [pouf]1213-pouf ! "[63-poirot] [he]63-poirot screwed up [his]63-poirot cherub - like face , and puffed comically enough " blow them away ! "[63-poirot]

" That 's all very well , "[0-i] [I]0-i objected , " but how are [you]63-poirot going to decide what is important , and what is n't ? That always seems the difficulty to [me]0-i . "[0-i]

[Poirot]63-poirot shook [his]63-poirot head energetically . [He]63-poirot was now arranging [his]63-poirot moustache with exquisite care .

" Not so . _ [Voyons]71-voyons ! _ One fact leads to another so [we]1212-we continue . Does the next fit in with that ? _ A merveille ! _ Good ! [We]1212-we can proceed . This next little fact no ! Ah , that is curious ! There is something missing a link in the chain that is not there . [We]1212-we examine . [We]1212-we search . And that little curious fact , that possibly paltry little detail that will not tally , [we]1212-we put it here ! "[63-poirot] [He]63-poirot made an extravagant gesture with [his]63-poirot hand . " It is significant ! It is tremendous ! "[63-poirot]

" [Y]0-i es "[63-poirot]

" Ah ! "[63-poirot] [Poirot]63-poirot shook [his]63-poirot forefinger so fiercely at [me]0-i that [I]0-i quailed before it . " Beware ! Peril to the detective who says : It is so small it does not matter . [It]1214-it will not agree . [I]0-i will forget it . ' That way lies confusion ! Everything matters . "[0-i]

" [I]63-poirot know . [You]0-i always told [me]63-poirot that . That 's why [I]63-poirot have gone into all the details of this thing whether they seemed to [me]63-poirot relevant or not . "[63-poirot]

" And [I]0-i am pleased with [you]0-i . [You]0-i have a good memory , and [you]0-i have given [me]0-i the facts faithfully . Of the order in which [you]0-i present them , [I]0-i say nothing truly , it is deplorable ! But [I]0-i make allowances [you]0-i are upset . To that [I]0-i attribute the circumstance that [you]0-i have omitted one fact of paramount importance . "[0-i]

" What is that ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" [You]0-i have not told [me]410-me if [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp ate well last night . "[410-me]

[I]0-i stared at [him]410-me . Surely the war had affected [the little man]411-the little man 's brain . [He]410-me was carefully engaged in brushing [his]410-me coat before putting it on , and seemed wholly engrossed in the task .

" [I]0-i do n't remember , "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " And , anyway , [I]0-i do n't see "[0-i]

" [You]0-i do not see ? But it is of the first importance . "[410-me]

" [I]0-i ca n't see why , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , rather nettled . " As far as [I]0-i can remember , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp did n't eat much . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp was obviously upset , and it had taken [her]44-mrs. inglethorp appetite away . That was only natural . "[0-i]

" Yes , "[63-poirot] said [Poirot]63-poirot thoughtfully , " it was only natural . "[63-poirot]

[He]63-poirot opened a drawer , and took out a small despatch - case , then turned to [me]0-i .

" Now [I]63-poirot am ready . [We]412-we will proceed to [the ch teau]1215-the ch teau , and study matters on the spot . Excuse [me]63-poirot , _ mon ami _ , [you]0-i dressed in haste , and [your]0-i tie is on one side . Permit [me]63-poirot . "[63-poirot] With a deft gesture , [he]63-poirot rearranged it .

" _ a y est ! _ Now , shall [we]412-we start ? "[63-poirot]

[We]412-we hurried up [the village]1124-the village , and turned in at the lodge gates . [Poirot]63-poirot stopped for a moment , and gazed sorrowfully over [the beautiful expanse of park]414-the beautiful expanse of park , still glittering with morning dew .

" So beautiful , so beautiful , and yet , [the poor family , plunged in sorrow , prostrated with grief]1216-the poor family , plunged in sorrow , prostrated with grief . "[63-poirot]

[He]63-poirot looked at [me]0-i keenly as [he]63-poirot spoke , and [I]0-i was aware that [I]0-i reddened under [his]63-poirot prolonged gaze .

Was [the family]130-the family prostrated by grief ? Was the sorrow at [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's death so great ? [I]0-i realized that there was an emotional lack in the atmosphere . [The dead woman]416-the dead woman had not the gift of commanding love . [Her]416-the dead woman death was a shock and a distress , but [she]416-the dead woman would not be passionately regretted .

[Poirot]63-poirot seemed to follow [my]0-i thoughts . [He]63-poirot nodded [his]63-poirot head gravely .

" No , [you]0-i are right , "[63-poirot] [he]63-poirot said , " it is not as though there was a blood tie . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp has been kind and generous to [these Cavendishes]1217-these cavendishes , but [she]44-mrs. inglethorp was not [[their]1217-these cavendishes own mother]154-their own mother . [Blood]72-blood tells always remember that blood tells . "[63-poirot]

" [Poirot]63-poirot , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " [I]0-i wish [you]63-poirot would tell [me]0-i why [you]63-poirot wanted to know if [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp ate well last night ? [I]0-i have been turning it over in [my]0-i mind , but [I]0-i ca n't see how it has anything to do with the matter ? "[0-i]

[He]63-poirot was silent for a minute or two as [we]417-we walked along , but finally [he]63-poirot said :

" [I]63-poirot do not mind telling [you]0-i though , as [you]0-i know , it is not [my]63-poirot habit to explain until the end is reached . The present contention is that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp died of strychnine poisoning , presumably administered in [her]44-mrs. inglethorp coffee . "[63-poirot]

" Yes ? "[63-poirot]

" Well , what time was the coffee served ? "[63-poirot]

" About eight o'clock . "[63-poirot]

" Therefore [she]44-mrs. inglethorp drank it between then and half - past eight certainly not much later . Well , strychnine is a fairly rapid poison . Its effects would be felt very soon , probably in about an hour . Yet , in [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's case , the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five o'clock the next morning : nine hours ! But a heavy meal , taken at about the same time as the poison , might retard its effects , though hardly to that extent . Still , it is a possibility to be taken into account . But , according to [you]0-i , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp ate very little for supper , and yet the symptoms do not develop until early the next morning ! Now that is a curious circumstance , [[my]63-poirot friend]129-my friend . Something may arise at the autopsy to explain it . In the meantime , remember it . "[63-poirot]

As [we]417-we neared [the house]1063-the house , [John]32-john came out and met [us]417-we . [His]32-john face looked weary and haggard .

" This is a very dreadful business , [Monsieur Poirot]31-poirot , "[32-john] [he]32-john said . " [Hastings]61-hastings has explained to [you]0-i that [we]417-we are anxious for no publicity ? "[32-john]

" [I]32-john comprehend perfectly . "[32-john]

" [You]0-i see , it is only suspicion so far . [We]417-we have nothing to go upon . "[32-john]

" Precisely . It is a matter of precaution only . "[32-john]

[John]32-john turned to [me]0-i , taking out [his]32-john cigarette - case , and lighting a cigarette as [he]32-john did so .

" [You]0-i know that fellow [Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp is back ? "[32-john]

" Yes . [I]32-john met [him]31-poirot . "[32-john]

[John]32-john flung the match into an adjacent flower bed , a proceeding which was too much for [Poirot]31-poirot 's feelings . [He]32-john retrieved it , and buried it neatly .

" It 's jolly difficult to know how to treat [him]31-poirot . "[32-john]

" That difficulty will not exist long , "[31-poirot] pronounced [Poirot]31-poirot quietly .

[John]32-john looked puzzled , not quite understanding the portent of this cryptic saying . [He]32-john handed the two keys which [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein had given [him]32-john to [me]0-i .

" [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein considered it advisable . "[31-poirot]

[We]419-us went up together to [the room of the tragedy]420-the room of the tragedy . For convenience [I]0-i append a plan of [the room]230-the room and the principal articles of furniture in [it]230-the room .

[ Illustration ]

[Poirot]31-poirot locked the door on the inside , and proceeded to a minute inspection of [the room]230-the room . [He]31-poirot darted from one object to the other with the agility of a grasshopper . [I]0-i remained by the door , fearing to obliterate any clues . [Poirot]31-poirot , however , did not seem grateful to [me]0-i for [my]0-i forbearance .

" What have [you]0-i , [[my]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot cried , " that [you]0-i remain there like how do [you]0-i say it ? ah , yes , the stuck pig ? "[31-poirot]

[I]0-i explained that [I]0-i was afraid of obliterating any foot - marks .

" Foot - marks ? But what an idea ! There has already been practically [an army in [the room]230-the room]1222-an army in the room ! What foot - marks are [we]1224-we likely to find ? No , come [here]1157-here and aid [me]31-poirot in [my]31-poirot search . [I]31-poirot will put down [my]31-poirot little case until [I]31-poirot need it . "[31-poirot]

[He]31-poirot did so , on the round table by the window , but it was an ill - advised proceeding ; for , the top of it being loose , it tilted up , and precipitated the despatch - case on the floor .

" _ Eh voil une table ! _ "[31-poirot] cried [Poirot]31-poirot . " Ah , [[my]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , one may live in [a big house]1227-a big house and yet have no comfort . "[31-poirot]

After which piece of moralizing , [he]31-poirot resumed [his]31-poirot search .

A small purple despatch - case , with a key in the lock , on the writing - table , engaged [his]31-poirot attention for some time . [He]31-poirot took out the key from the lock , and passed it to [me]0-i to inspect . [I]0-i saw nothing peculiar , however . It was an ordinary key of the Yale type , with a bit of twisted wire through the handle .

Next , [he]31-poirot examined the framework of the door [we]423-we had broken in , assuring [himself]31-poirot that the bolt had really been shot . Then [he]31-poirot went to the door opposite leading into [[Cynthia]68-poor cynthia 's room]349-cynthia 's room . That door was also bolted , as [I]0-i had stated . However , [he]31-poirot went to the length of unbolting it , and opening and shutting it several times ; this [he]31-poirot did with the utmost precaution against making any noise . Suddenly something in the bolt itself seemed to rivet [his]31-poirot attention . [He]31-poirot examined it carefully , and then , nimbly whipping out a pair of small forceps from [his]31-poirot case , [he]31-poirot drew out some minute particle which [he]31-poirot carefully sealed up in a tiny envelope .

On the chest of drawers there was a tray with a spirit lamp and a small saucepan on it . A small quantity of a dark fluid remained in the saucepan , and an empty cup and saucer that had been drunk out of stood near it .

[I]0-i wondered how [I]0-i could have been so unobservant as to overlook this . Here was a clue worth having . [Poirot]31-poirot delicately dipped [his]31-poirot finger into liquid , and tasted it gingerly . [He]31-poirot made a grimace .

" Cocoa with [I]31-poirot think rum in it . "[31-poirot]

[He]31-poirot passed on to the debris on the floor , where the table by the bed had been overturned . A reading - lamp , some books , matches , a bunch of keys , and the crushed fragments of a coffee - cup lay scattered about .

" Ah , this is curious , "[31-poirot] said [Poirot]31-poirot .

" [I]31-poirot must confess that [I]31-poirot see nothing particularly curious about it . "[31-poirot]

" [You]31-poirot do not ? Observe the lamp the chimney is broken in two places ; they lie there as they fell . But see , the coffee - cup is absolutely smashed to powder . "[31-poirot]

" Well , "[0-i] [I]0-i said wearily , " [I]0-i suppose [someone]1149-someone must have stepped on it . "[0-i]

" Exactly , "[31-poirot] said [Poirot]31-poirot , in an odd voice . " [Someone]1149-someone stepped on it . "[31-poirot]

[He]31-poirot rose from [his]31-poirot knees , and walked slowly across to the mantelpiece , where [he]31-poirot stood abstractedly fingering the ornaments , and straightening them a trick of [his]31-poirot when [he]31-poirot was agitated .

" _ Mon ami _ , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot said , turning to [me]0-i , " [somebody]1230-somebody stepped on that cup , grinding it to powder , and the reason [they]1230-somebody did so was either because it contained strychnine or which is far more serious because it did not contain strychnine ! "[31-poirot]

[I]0-i made no reply . [I]0-i was bewildered , but [I]0-i knew that it was no good asking [him]31-poirot to explain . In a moment or two [he]31-poirot roused [himself]31-poirot , and went on with [his]31-poirot investigations . [He]31-poirot picked up the bunch of keys from the floor , and twirling them round in [his]31-poirot fingers finally selected one , very bright and shining , which [he]31-poirot tried in the lock of the purple despatch - case . It fitted , and [he]31-poirot opened the box , but after a moment 's hesitation , closed and relocked it , and slipped the bunch of keys , as well as the key that had originally stood in the lock , into [his]31-poirot own pocket .

" [I]31-poirot have no authority to go through these papers . But it should be done at once ! "[31-poirot]

[He]31-poirot then made a very careful examination of the drawers of the wash - stand . Crossing [the room]230-the room to the left - hand window , a round stain , hardly visible on the dark brown carpet , seemed to interest [him]31-poirot particularly . [He]31-poirot went down on [his]31-poirot knees , examining it minutely even going so far as to smell it .

Finally , [he]31-poirot poured a few drops of the cocoa into a test tube , sealing it up carefully . [His]31-poirot next proceeding was to take out a little notebook .

" [We]1231-we have found in [this room]1232-this room , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot said , writing busily , " six points of interest . Shall [I]31-poirot enumerate them , or will [you]0-i ? "[31-poirot]

" Well , [sir]1184-sir , [I]64-dorcas happened to be going along [the hall]297-the hall outside yesterday "[64-dorcas]

[He]31-poirot pulled a crumpled envelope out of [his]31-poirot pocket , and tossed it over to [me]0-i . It was rather a curious document . A plain , dirty looking old envelope with a few words scrawled across it , apparently at random . The following is a facsimile of it .

[ Illustration ]

CHAPTER V. " IT ISN'T [STRYCHNINE]15-strychnine , IS IT ? "[31-poirot]

" Where did [you]31-poirot find this ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked [Poirot]31-poirot , in lively curiosity .

" In the waste - paper basket . [You]31-poirot recognise the handwriting ? "[31-poirot]

" Yes , it is [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's . But what does it mean ? "[0-i]

[Poirot]31-poirot shrugged [his]31-poirot shoulders .

" [I]31-poirot can not say but it is suggestive . "[31-poirot]

A wild idea flashed across [me]0-i . Was it possible that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's mind was deranged ? Had [she]44-mrs. inglethorp some fantastic idea of demoniacal possession ? And , if that were so , was it not also possible that [she]44-mrs. inglethorp might have taken [her]44-mrs. inglethorp own life ?

[I]0-i was about to expound these theories to [Poirot]31-poirot , when [his]31-poirot own words distracted [me]0-i .

" Come , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot said , " now to examine the coffee - cups ! "[31-poirot]

" [[My]31-poirot dear]1106-my dear [Poirot]31-poirot ! What on earth is the good of that , now that [we]1373-we know about the cocoa ? "[31-poirot]

" Oh , _ l l ! _ That miserable cocoa ! "[31-poirot] cried [Poirot]31-poirot flippantly .

[He]31-poirot laughed with apparent enjoyment , raising [his]31-poirot arms to heaven in mock despair , in what [I]0-i could not but consider the worst possible taste .

" Who ? That is the question . Why ? Ah , if [I]31-poirot only knew . When ? Since [I]31-poirot was [here]1157-here an hour ago . As to the door being locked , it is a very ordinary lock . Probably any other of the doorkeys in [this passage]1491-this passage would fit it . "[31-poirot]

[We]516-us stared at [one another]517-one another blankly . [Poirot]31-poirot had walked over to the mantelpiece . " See here , it was like this , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot said at last . " There was something in that case some piece of evidence , slight in itself perhaps , but still enough of a clue to connect [the murderer]1087-the murderer with the crime . It was vital to [him]31-poirot that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its significance appreciated . Therefore , [he]31-poirot took the risk , the great risk , of coming in [here]1157-here . Finding the case locked , [he]31-poirot was obliged to force it , thus betraying [his]31-poirot presence . " But what was it ? "[31-poirot]

[He]31-poirot rushed like [a madman]518-a madman from [the room]230-the room , and [I]0-i followed [him]31-poirot as soon as [I]0-i had sufficiently recovered [my]0-i wits . But , by the time [I]0-i had reached the top of the stairs , [he]31-poirot was out of sight .

[Mary Cavendish]41-mary was standing where the staircase branched , staring down into [the hall]297-the hall in the direction in which [he]31-poirot had disappeared .

" And supposing [[the Coroner]1564-the coroner 's jury]1565-the coroner 's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder against [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . What becomes of [your]63-poirot theories , then ? "[31-poirot]

[He]546-the extraordinary little man was so tremendously sure of [himself]546-the extraordinary little man . As though [he]546-the extraordinary little man read [my]0-i thoughts , [he]546-the extraordinary little man nodded gently .

" Oh , yes , _ mon ami _ , [I]546-the extraordinary little man would do what [I]546-the extraordinary little man say . "[546-the extraordinary little man] [He]546-the extraordinary little man got up and laid [his]546-the extraordinary little man hand on [my]0-i shoulder . [His]546-the extraordinary little man physiognomy underwent a complete change . Tears came into [his]546-the extraordinary little man eyes . " In all this , [you]0-i see , [I]546-the extraordinary little man think of [that poor Mrs. Inglethorp who is dead]1570-that poor mrs. inglethorp who is dead . [She]1570-that poor mrs. inglethorp who is dead was not extravagantly loved no . But [she]1570-that poor mrs. inglethorp who is dead was very good to [us]1571-us Belgians [I]546-the extraordinary little man owe [her]1570-that poor mrs. inglethorp who is dead a debt . "[546-the extraordinary little man]

[I]0-i endeavoured to interrupt , but [Poirot]63-poirot swept on .

" Let [me]546-the extraordinary little man tell [you]0-i this , [Hastings]40-miss howard . [She]1570-that poor mrs. inglethorp who is dead would never forgive [me]546-the extraordinary little man if [I]546-the extraordinary little man let [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp , [[her]1570-that poor mrs. inglethorp who is dead husband]203-her husband , be arrested _ now _ when a word from [me]546-the extraordinary little man could save [him]37-mr. inglethorp ! "[546-the extraordinary little man]

CHAPTER VI .

THE INQUEST

In the interval before the inquest , [Poirot]63-poirot was unfailing in [his]63-poirot activity . Twice [he]63-poirot was closeted with [Mr. Wells]75-mr. wells . [He]63-poirot also took long walks into [the country]1465-the country . [I]0-i rather resented [his]63-poirot not taking [me]0-i into [his]63-poirot confidence , the more so as [I]0-i could not in the least guess what [he]63-poirot was driving at .

It occurred to [me]0-i that [he]63-poirot might have been making inquiries at [[Raikes]56-mrs. raikes 's farm]548-raikes 's farm ; so , finding [him]63-poirot out when [I]0-i called at [Leastways Cottage]16-leastways cottage on Wednesday evening , [I]0-i walked over there by [the fields]549-the fields , hoping to meet [him]63-poirot . But there was no sign of [him]63-poirot , and [I]0-i hesitated to go right up to [the farm itself]550-the farm itself . As [I]0-i walked away , [I]0-i met an aged rustic , who leered at [me]0-i cunningly .

" [You'm]0-i from [the Hall]297-the hall , bain't [you]0-i ? "[63-poirot] [he]63-poirot asked .

" Yes . [I]63-poirot 'm looking for [a friend of [mine]63-poirot whom [I]63-poirot thought might have walked this way]1574-a friend of mine whom i thought might have walked this way . "[63-poirot]

" [A little chap]1575-a little chap ? As waves [his]1575-a little chap hands when [he]1575-a little chap talks ? [One of [them]1577-them [Belgies]87-belgies from [the village]1124-the village]1576-one of them belgies from the village ? "[63-poirot]

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said eagerly . " [He]1574-a friend of mine whom i thought might have walked this way has been [here]1157-here , then ? "[0-i]

" Oh , ay , [he]1574-a friend of mine whom i thought might have walked this way 's been [here]1157-here , right enough . More'n once too . [Friend of yours]1581-friend of yours , is [he]1574-a friend of mine whom i thought might have walked this way ? Ah , [[you]0-i gentlemen from [the Hall]297-the hall]1582-you gentlemen from the hall you'm [a pretty lot]1584-a pretty lot ! "[551-he] And [he]551-he leered more jocosely than ever .

" Why , do [the gentlemen from [the Hall]297-the hall]1585-the gentlemen from the hall come here often ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , as carelessly as [I]0-i could .

[He]551-he winked at [me]0-i knowingly .

" _ One _ does , [mister]1587-mister . Naming no names , mind . And [a very liberal gentleman]1588-a very liberal gentleman too ! Oh , thank [you]551-he , [sir]1184-sir , [I]551-he 'm sure . "[551-he]

[I]0-i walked on sharply . [Evelyn Howard]36-evelyn howard had been right then , and [I]0-i experienced a sharp twinge of disgust , as [I]0-i thought of [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp 's liberality with [another woman]552-another woman 's money . Had that piquant gipsy face been at the bottom of the crime , or was it the baser mainspring of money ? Probably a judicious mixture of both .

On one point , [Poirot]63-poirot seemed to have a curious obsession . [He]63-poirot once or twice observed to [me]0-i that [he]63-poirot thought [Dorcas]64-dorcas must have made an error in fixing the time of the quarrel . [He]63-poirot suggested to [her]64-dorcas repeatedly that it was four - thirty , and not four o'clock when [she]64-dorcas had heard the voices .

But [Dorcas]64-dorcas was unshaken . Quite an hour , or even more , had elapsed between the time when [she]64-dorcas had heard the voices and five o'clock , when [she]64-dorcas had taken tea to [[her]64-dorcas mistress]553-her mistress .

The inquest was held on Friday at [[the Stylites Arms]554-the stylites arms in [the village]1124-the village]555-the stylites arms in the village . [Poirot]63-poirot and [I]0-i sat together , not being required to give evidence .

The preliminaries were gone through . [The jury]557-the jury viewed the body , and [John Cavendish]32-john gave evidence of identification .

Further questioned , [he]32-john described [his]32-john awakening in the early hours of the morning , and the circumstances of [[his]32-john mother]137-his mother 's death .

The medical evidence was next taken . There was a breathless hush , and every eye was fixed on [the famous [London]12-london specialist , who was known to be one of [the greatest authorities of the day on the subject of toxicology]560-the greatest authorities of the day on the subject of toxicology]559-the famous london specialist , who was known to be one of the greatest authorities of the day on the subject of toxicology .

In a few brief words , [he]559-the famous london specialist , who was known to be one of the greatest authorities of the day on the subject of toxicology summed up the result of the post - mortem . Shorn of its medical phraseology and technicalities , it amounted to the fact that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp had met [her]44-mrs. inglethorp death as the result of strychnine poisoning . Judging from the quantity recovered , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp must have taken not less than three - quarters of a grain of strychnine , but probably one grain or slightly over .

" Is it possible that [she]44-mrs. inglethorp could have swallowed the poison by accident ? "[1564-the coroner] asked [the Coroner]1564-the coroner .

" [I]0-i should consider it very unlikely . Strychnine is not used for domestic purposes , as some poisons are , and there are restrictions placed on its sale . "[0-i]

" Does anything in [your]0-i examination lead [you]0-i to determine how the poison was administered ? "[0-i]

" No . "[0-i]

" [You]0-i arrived at [Styles]4-styles before [Dr. Wilkins]66-dr. wilkins , [I]0-i believe ? "[0-i]

" That is so . [The motor]232-the motor met [me]0-i just outside [the lodge]181-the lodge gates , and [I]0-i hurried [there]140-there as fast as [I]0-i could . "[0-i]

" Will [you]0-i relate to [us]1593-us exactly what happened next ? "[0-i]

" [I]0-i entered [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's room]433-mrs. inglethorp 's room . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp was at that moment in a typical tetanic convulsion . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp turned towards [me]0-i , and gasped out : [Alfred Alfred]1595-alfred alfred ' "[0-i]

" Could the strychnine have been administered in [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's after - dinner coffee which was taken to [her]44-mrs. inglethorp by [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband ? "[0-i]

" Possibly , but strychnine is a fairly rapid drug in [its]1597-its action . The symptoms appear from one to two hours after it has been swallowed . It is retarded under certain conditions , none of which , however , appear to have been present in this case . [I]0-i presume [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp took the coffee after dinner about eight o'clock , whereas the symptoms did not manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning , which , on the face of it , points to the drug having been taken much later in the evening . "[0-i]

" [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp was in the habit of drinking a cup of cocoa in the middle of the night . Could the strychnine have been administered in that ? "[0-i]

" No , [I]0-i [myself]0-i took a sample of the cocoa remaining in the saucepan and had it analysed . There was no strychnine present . "[0-i]

[I]0-i heard [Poirot]63-poirot chuckle softly beside [me]0-i .

" How did [you]0-i know ? "[0-i] [I]0-i whispered .

" Listen . "[0-i]

" [I]319-the doctor should say "[319-the doctor] [the doctor]319-the doctor was continuing " that [I]319-the doctor would have been considerably surprised at any other result . "[319-the doctor]

" Why ? "[319-the doctor]

" Simply because strychnine has an unusually bitter taste . It can be detected in a solution of one in seventy thousand , and can only be disguised by some strongly flavoured substance . Cocoa would be quite powerless to mask it . "[319-the doctor]

[One of [the jury]557-the jury]563-one of the jury wanted to know if the same objection applied to coffee .

" No . Coffee has a bitter taste of its own which would probably cover the taste of strychnine . "[557-the jury]

" Then [you]563-one of the jury consider it more likely that the drug was administered in the coffee , but that for some unknown reason [its]1598-its action was delayed . "[66-dr. wilkins]

" Yes , but , the cup being completely smashed , there is no possibility of analyzing its contents . "[557-the jury]

This concluded [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein 's evidence . [Dr. Wilkins]66-dr. wilkins corroborated it on all points . Sounded as to the possibility of suicide , [he]66-dr. wilkins repudiated it utterly . [The deceased]565-the deceased , [he]66-dr. wilkins said , suffered from a weak heart , but otherwise enjoyed perfect health , and was of a cheerful and well - balanced disposition . [She]565-the deceased would be one of [the last people to take [her]565-the deceased own life]566-the last people to take her own life .

[Lawrence Cavendish]52-lawrence was next called . [His]66-dr. wilkins evidence was quite unimportant , being a mere repetition of that of [[his]66-dr. wilkins brother]277-his brother . Just as [he]66-dr. wilkins was about to step down , [he]66-dr. wilkins paused , and said rather hesitatingly :

" [I]66-dr. wilkins should like to make a suggestion if [I]66-dr. wilkins may ? "[66-dr. wilkins]

[He]66-dr. wilkins glanced deprecatingly at [the Coroner]1564-the coroner , who replied briskly :

" Certainly , [Mr. Cavendish]52-lawrence , [we]1599-we are here to arrive at the truth of this matter , and welcome anything that may lead to further elucidation . "[66-dr. wilkins]

" It is just an idea of mine , "[52-lawrence] explained [Lawrence]52-lawrence . " Of course [I]52-lawrence may be quite wrong , but it still seems to [me]52-lawrence that [[my]52-lawrence mother]1050-my mother 's death might be accounted for by natural means . "[52-lawrence]

" How do [you]52-lawrence make that out , [Mr. Cavendish]52-lawrence ? "[66-dr. wilkins]

" [[My]52-lawrence mother]1050-my mother , at the time of [her]1050-my mother death , and for some time before it , was taking a tonic containing strychnine . "[52-lawrence]

" Ah ! "[1564-the coroner] said [the Coroner]1564-the coroner .

[The jury]557-the jury looked up , interested .

" [I]52-lawrence believe , "[52-lawrence] continued [Lawrence]52-lawrence , " that there have been cases where the cumulative effect of a drug , administered for some time , has ended by causing death . Also , is it not possible that [she]1050-my mother may have taken an overdose of [her]1050-my mother medicine by accident ? "[52-lawrence]

" This is the first [we]1599-we have heard of [the deceased]565-the deceased taking strychnine at the time of [her]1050-my mother death . [We]1599-we are much obliged to [you]52-lawrence , [Mr. Cavendish]52-lawrence . "[557-the jury]

[Dr. Wilkins]66-dr. wilkins was recalled and ridiculed the idea .

" What [Mr. Cavendish]52-lawrence suggests is quite impossible . [Any doctor]1603-any doctor would tell [you]52-lawrence the same . Strychnine is , in a certain sense , a cumulative poison , but it would be quite impossible for it to result in sudden death in this way . There would have to be a long period of chronic symptoms which would at once have attracted [my]52-lawrence attention . The whole thing is absurd . "[52-lawrence]

" And the second suggestion ? That [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp may have inadvertently taken an overdose ? "[319-the doctor]

" Three , or even four doses , would not have resulted in death . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp always had an extra large amount of medicine made up at a time , as [she]44-mrs. inglethorp dealt with [Coot]88-coot 's , [the Cash Chemists in [Tadminster]8-tadminster]1604-the cash chemists in tadminster . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp would have had to take very nearly the whole bottle to account for the amount of strychnine found at the post - mortem . "[52-lawrence]

" Then [you]1564-the coroner consider that [we]1605-we may dismiss the tonic as not being in any way instrumental in causing [her]44-mrs. inglethorp death ? "[319-the doctor]

" Certainly . The supposition is ridiculous . "[52-lawrence]

[The same juryman who had interrupted before here]571-the same juryman who had interrupted before here suggested that [the chemist who made up the medicine]572-the chemist who made up the medicine might have committed an error .

" That , of course , is always possible , "[319-the doctor] replied [the doctor]319-the doctor .

But [Dorcas]64-dorcas , who was [the next witness called]574-the next witness called , dispelled even that possibility . The medicine had not been newly made up . On the contrary , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp had taken the last dose on the day of [her]44-mrs. inglethorp death .

So the question of the tonic was finally abandoned , and [the Coroner]1564-the coroner proceeded with [his]1564-the coroner task . Having elicited from [Dorcas]64-dorcas how [she]64-dorcas had been awakened by the violent ringing of [[her]64-dorcas mistress]553-her mistress 's bell , and had subsequently roused [the household]1209-the household , [he]1564-the coroner passed to the subject of the quarrel on the preceding afternoon .

[Dorcas]64-dorcas 's evidence on this point was substantially what [Poirot]63-poirot and [I]0-i had already heard , so [I]0-i will not repeat it here .

[The next witness]578-the next witness was [Mary Cavendish]41-mary . [She]41-mary stood very upright , and spoke in a low , clear , and perfectly composed voice . In answer to [the Coroner]1564-the coroner 's question , [she]41-mary told how , [her]41-mary alarm clock having aroused [her]41-mary at four - thirty as usual , [she]41-mary was dressing , when [she]41-mary was startled by the sound of something heavy falling .

" [I]41-mary ? "[41-mary]

[I]0-i caught the momentary gleam of [her]41-mary tawny eyes as [she]41-mary raised them . [Amy Hill]89-amy hill , [shop assistant]587-shop assistant , was next called , and deposed to having sold a will form on the afternoon of the 17th to [William Earl]74-william earl , [under - gardener at [Styles]4-styles]588-under - gardener at styles .

[Cynthia Murdoch]48-cynthia came next . [She]48-cynthia had , however , little to tell . [She]48-cynthia had known nothing of the tragedy , until awakened by [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish .

" [Miss Howard]40-miss howard . "[33-mrs. cavendish]

[Miss Howard]40-miss howard produced the letter written to [her]33-mrs. cavendish by [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp on the evening of the 17th . " [I]1564-the coroner fear it does not help [us]591-our much , "[1564-the coroner] said [the Coroner]1564-the coroner , with a sigh . " There is no mention of any of the events of that afternoon . "[1564-the coroner]

" Plain as a pikestaff to [me]40-miss howard , "[40-miss howard] said [Miss Howard]40-miss howard shortly . " It shows clearly enough that [[my]40-miss howard poor old friend]1616-my poor old friend had just found out [she]1616-my poor old friend 'd been made a fool of ! "[40-miss howard]

" It says nothing of the kind in the letter , "[1564-the coroner] [the Coroner]1564-the coroner pointed out .

" No , because [Emily]1617-emily never could bear to put [herself]1617-emily in the wrong . But _ [I]601-a public character _ know [her]1617-emily . [She]1617-emily wanted [me]601-a public character back . But [she]1617-emily was n't going to own that [I]601-a public character 'd been right . [She]1617-emily went round about . [Mr. Wells]75-mr. wells smiled faintly . So , [I]0-i noticed , did [several of [the jury]557-the jury]599-several of the jury . [Miss Howard]40-miss howard was obviously quite [a public character]601-a public character .

" Anyway , all this tomfoolery is a great waste of time , "[507-the lady] continued [the lady]507-the lady , glancing up and down [the jury]557-the jury disparagingly . " Talk talk talk ! When all the time [we]1619-we know perfectly well "[507-the lady]

" Thank [you]507-the lady , [Miss Howard]40-miss howard , that is all . "[1564-the coroner]

[I]0-i fancy [he]1564-the coroner breathed a sigh of relief when [she]507-the lady complied .

Then came the sensation of the day . [The Coroner]1564-the coroner called [Albert Mace]91-albert mace , [[chemist]606-chemist 's assistant]607-chemist 's assistant .

[It]91-albert mace was [[our]608-our agitated young man of the pale face]609-our agitated young man of the pale face . In answer to [the Coroner]1564-the coroner 's questions , [he]91-albert mace explained that [he]91-albert mace was [a qualified pharmacist]611-a qualified pharmacist , but had only recently come to [this particular shop]612-this particular shop , as [the assistant formerly there]613-the assistant formerly there had just been called up for [the army]614-the army .

These preliminaries completed , [the Coroner]1564-the coroner proceeded to business .

" [Mr. Mace]84-mr. mace , have [you]84-mr. mace lately sold strychnine to [any unauthorized person]1620-any unauthorized person ? "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

" Yes , [sir]1184-sir . "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

" When was this ? "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

" Last Monday night . "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

" Monday ? Not Tuesday ? "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

" No , [sir]1184-sir , Monday , the 16th . "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

" Will [you]84-mr. mace tell [us]1623-us to whom [you]84-mr. mace sold it ? "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

[You]616-you could have heard a pin drop .

" Yes , [sir]1184-sir . It was to [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . "[611-a qualified pharmacist]

Every eye turned simultaneously to where [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp was sitting , impassive and wooden . [He]37-mr. inglethorp started slightly , as the damning words fell from [the young man]539-the young man 's lips . [I]0-i half thought [he]37-mr. inglethorp was going to rise from [his]37-mr. inglethorp chair , but [he]37-mr. inglethorp remained seated , although a remarkably well acted expression of astonishment rose on [his]37-mr. inglethorp face .

" [You]1184-sir are sure of what [you]84-mr. mace say ? "[1564-the coroner] asked [the Coroner]1564-the coroner sternly .

"[0-i]

" Why not now as much as before ? Nothing has changed . "[0-i]

" But the evidence is so conclusive . "[0-i]

" Yes , too conclusive . "[0-i]

[We]652-us turned in at the gate of [Leastways Cottage]16-leastways cottage , and proceeded up [the now familiar stairs]653-the now familiar stairs .

" How do [you]85-poirot make that out ? "[652-us]

" Because , so long as the evidence against [him]37-mr. inglethorp was vague and intangible , it was very hard to disprove . [I]0-i was silent . And in a minute or two , [Poirot]85-poirot continued :

" Let [us]652-us look at the matter like this . Here is [a man]196-a man , let [us]652-us say , who sets out to poison [[his]196-a man wife]149-his wife . [He]196-a man has lived by [his]196-a man wits as the saying goes . Presumably , therefore , [he]196-a man has some wits . [He]196-a man is not altogether [a fool]1661-a fool . Well , how does [he]196-a man set about it ? [He]196-a man goes boldly to [the village chemist 's]1696-the village chemist 's and purchases strychnine under [his]196-a man own name , with a trumped up story about a dog which is bound to be proved absurd . [He]196-a man does not employ the poison that night . No , [he]196-a man waits until [he]196-a man has had a violent quarrel with [her]149-his wife , of which [the whole household]342-the whole household is cognisant , and which naturally directs [their]342-the whole household suspicions upon [him]196-a man . [He]196-a man prepares no defence no shadow of an alibi , yet [he]196-a man knows [[the chemist]1698-the chemist 's assistant]1699-the chemist 's assistant must necessarily come forward with the facts . Bah ! Do not ask [me]85-poirot to believe that [any man]361-any man could be so idiotic ! CHAPTER VIII . FRESH SUSPICIONS

There was a moment 's stupefied silence . [Japp]92-japp , who was the least surprised of [any of [us]684-us]683-any of us , was the first to speak .

" [My]92-japp word , "[92-japp] [he]92-japp cried , " [you]1755-you 're [the goods]1759-the goods ! And no mistake , [Mr. Poirot]85-poirot ! [These witnesses of yours]1760-these witnesses of yours are all right , [I]92-japp suppose ? "[92-japp]

" _ Voil ! _ [I]683-any of us have prepared a list of [them]1760-these witnesses of yours names and addresses . [You]1755-you must see [them]1760-these witnesses of yours , of course . But [you]1755-you will find it all right . "[683-any of us]

" [I]92-japp 'm sure of that . "[92-japp] [Japp]92-japp lowered [his]92-japp voice . " [I]92-japp 'm much obliged to [you]1755-you . [A pretty mare]1761-a pretty mare 's nest arresting [him]37-mr. inglethorp would have been . "[92-japp] [He]92-japp turned to [Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp . " But , if [you]44-mrs. inglethorp 'll excuse [me]92-japp , [sir]1184-sir , why could n't [you]44-mrs. inglethorp say all this at the inquest ? "[92-japp]

" [I]85-poirot will tell [you]44-mrs. inglethorp why , "[85-poirot] interrupted [Poirot]85-poirot . " There was a certain rumour "[85-poirot]

" A most malicious and utterly untrue one , "[37-mr. inglethorp] interrupted [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp in an agitated voice .

" And [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp was anxious to have no scandal revived just at present . Am [I]85-poirot right ? "[85-poirot]

" Quite right . "[44-mrs. inglethorp] [Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp nodded . " With [[my]44-mrs. inglethorp poor Emily]1210-my poor emily not yet buried , can [you]1755-you wonder [I]44-mrs. inglethorp was anxious that no more lying rumours should be started . "[44-mrs. inglethorp]

" Between [you]1184-sir and [me]92-japp , [sir]1184-sir , "[92-japp] remarked [Japp]92-japp , " [I]92-japp 'd sooner have any amount of rumours than be arrested for murder . The papers , of course , had been full of the tragedy . Glaring headlines , sandwiched biographies of [every member of [the household]1209-the household]708-every member of the household , subtle innuendoes , the usual familiar tag about [the police]1084-the police having a clue . Nothing was spared [us]706-we . It was a slack time . The war was momentarily inactive , and the newspapers seized with avidity on this crime in fashionable life : " The Mysterious Affair at Styles "[708-every member of the household] was the topic of the moment .

Naturally it was very annoying for [the Cavendishes]100-the cavendishes . [The house]1063-the house was constantly besieged by [reporters]712-reporters , who were consistently denied admission , but who continued to haunt [the village]1124-the village and [the grounds]714-the grounds , where [they]712-reporters lay in wait with cameras , for [any unwary members of [the household]1209-the household]715-any unwary members of the household . [We]706-we all lived in a blast of publicity . [The Scotland Yard men]644-the scotland yard men came and went , examining , questioning , lynx - eyed and reserved of tongue . Towards what end [they]644-the scotland yard men were working , [we]706-we did not know . CHAPTER IX . [DR . BAUERSTEIN]103-dr . bauerstein

[I]0-i had had no opportunity as yet of passing on [Poirot]31-poirot 's message to [Lawrence]52-lawrence . But now , as [I]0-i strolled out on [the lawn]198-the lawn , still nursing a grudge against [[my]0-i friend]129-my friend 's high - handedness , [I]0-i saw [Lawrence]52-lawrence on [the croquet lawn]741-the croquet lawn , aimlessly knocking a couple of very ancient balls about , with a still more ancient mallet .

It struck [me]0-i that it would be a good opportunity to deliver [my]0-i message . Otherwise , [Poirot]31-poirot [himself]31-poirot might relieve [me]0-i of it . It was true that [I]0-i did not quite gather [its]742-its purport , but [I]0-i flattered [myself]0-i that by [Lawrence]52-lawrence 's reply , and perhaps a little skillful cross - examination on [my]0-i part , [I]0-i should soon perceive its significance . Accordingly [I]0-i accosted [him]31-poirot .

" [I]0-i 've been looking for [you]31-poirot , "[0-i] [I]0-i remarked untruthfully .

" Have [you]31-poirot ? "[31-poirot]

" Yes . The truth is , [I]31-poirot 've got a message for [you]31-poirot from [Poirot]31-poirot . "[31-poirot]

" Yes ? "[31-poirot]

" [He]31-poirot told [me]0-i to wait until [I]0-i was alone with [you]31-poirot , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , dropping [my]0-i voice significantly , and watching [him]31-poirot intently out of the corner of [my]0-i eye . [I]0-i have always been rather good at what is called , [I]0-i believe , creating an atmosphere .

" Well ? "[0-i]

There was no change of expression in the dark melancholic face . Had [he]31-poirot any idea of what [I]0-i was about to say ?

" This is the message . "[0-i] [I]0-i dropped [my]0-i voice still lower . " Find the extra coffee - cup , and [you]31-poirot can rest in peace . ' "[0-i]

" What on earth does [he]31-poirot mean ? "[52-lawrence] [Lawrence]52-lawrence stared at [me]0-i in quite unaffected astonishment .

" Do n't [you]31-poirot know ? "[0-i]

" Not in the least . Do [you]31-poirot ? "[0-i]

[I]0-i was compelled to shake [my]0-i head .

" What extra coffee - cup ? "[0-i]

" [I]0-i do n't know . "[0-i]

" [Mr. Hastings]40-miss howard . "[38-cynthia]

" [Mr. Hastings]40-miss howard [you]38-cynthia are always so kind , and [you]38-cynthia know such a lot . "[38-cynthia]

"[38-cynthia] Suddenly [the poor child]788-the poor child burst out crying .

Thinking over the interview , it struck [me]0-i as being profoundly unsatisfactory .

It occurred to [me]0-i suddenly that [I]0-i would go down to [the village]1124-the village , and look up [Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein . CHAPTER X. THE ARREST

To [my]0-i extreme annoyance , [Poirot]31-poirot was not in , and [the old Belgian who answered [my]0-i knock]796-the old belgian who answered my knock informed [me]0-i that [he]796-the old belgian who answered my knock believed [he]796-the old belgian who answered my knock had gone to [London]12-london .

[I]0-i was dumbfounded . What on earth could [Poirot]31-poirot be doing in [London]12-london ! Was it a sudden decision on [his]31-poirot part , or had [he]31-poirot already made up [his]31-poirot mind when [he]31-poirot parted from [me]0-i a few hours earlier ?

[I]0-i retraced [my]0-i steps to [Styles]30-styles in some annoyance . With [Poirot]31-poirot away , [I]0-i was uncertain how to act . Had [he]31-poirot foreseen this arrest ? Had [he]31-poirot not , in all probability , been the cause of it ? Those questions [I]0-i could not resolve . But in the meantime what was [I]0-i to do ? Should [I]0-i announce the arrest openly at [Styles]4-styles , or not ? Though [I]0-i did not acknowledge it to [myself]0-i , the thought of [Mary Cavendish]41-mary was weighing on [me]0-i . Would it not be a terrible shock to [her]41-mary ? For the moment , [I]0-i set aside utterly any suspicions of [her]41-mary . [She]41-mary could not be implicated otherwise [I]0-i should have heard some hint of it .

Of course , there was no possibility of being able permanently to conceal [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein 's arrest from [her]41-mary . It would be announced in every newspaper on the morrow . Still , [I]0-i shrank from blurting it out . If only [Poirot]31-poirot had been accessible , [I]0-i could have asked [his]31-poirot advice . What possessed [him]31-poirot to go posting off to [London]12-london in this unaccountable way ?

In spite of [myself]0-i , [my]0-i opinion of [his]31-poirot sagacity was immeasurably heightened . [I]0-i would never have dreamt of suspecting [the doctor]319-the doctor , had not [Poirot]31-poirot put it into [my]0-i head . Yes , decidedly , [the little man]411-the little man was clever .

After some reflecting , [I]0-i decided to take [John]32-john into [my]0-i confidence , and leave [him]32-john to make the matter public or not , as [he]32-john thought fit .

[He]32-john gave vent to a prodigious whistle , as [I]0-i imparted the news .

" Great [Scott]109-scott ! [You]109-scott _ were _ right , then . [I]411-the little man could n't believe it at the time . "[411-the little man]

" No , it is astonishing until [you]109-scott get used to the idea , and see how it makes everything fit in . Now , what are [we]1970-we to do ? Of course , it will be generally known to - morrow . "[32-john]

[John]32-john reflected .

" Never mind , "[32-john] [he]32-john said at last , " [we]1970-we wo n't say anything at present . There is no need . As [you]0-i say , it will be known soon enough . "[32-john]

But to [my]0-i intense surprise , on getting down early the next morning , and eagerly opening the newspapers , there was not a word about the arrest ! There was a column of mere padding about " The Styles Poisoning Case , "[32-john] but nothing further . It was rather inexplicable , but [I]0-i supposed that , for some reason or other , [Japp]92-japp wished to keep it out of the papers . It worried [me]0-i just a little , for it suggested the possibility that there might be further arrests to come .

After breakfast , [I]0-i decided to go down to [the village]1124-the village , and see if [Poirot]31-poirot had returned yet ; but , before [I]0-i could start , a well - known face blocked one of the windows , and the well - known voice said :

" _ Bonjour , [mon ami]1971-mon ami ! _ "[31-poirot]

" [Poirot]31-poirot , "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed , with relief , and seizing [him]31-poirot by both hands , [I]0-i dragged [him]31-poirot into [the room]230-the room . " [I]0-i was never so glad to see [anyone]1030-anyone . Listen , [I]0-i have said nothing to [anybody]1790-anybody but [John]32-john . Is that right ? "[0-i]

" [[My]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , "[31-poirot] replied [Poirot]31-poirot , " [I]31-poirot do not know what [you]129-my friend are talking about . "[31-poirot]

" [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein 's arrest , of course , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered impatiently .

" Is [Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein arrested , then ? "[0-i]

" Did [you]129-my friend not know it ? "[0-i]

" Not the least in [the world]1122-the world . "[0-i] But , pausing a moment , [he]31-poirot added : " Still , it does not surprise [me]31-poirot . After all , [we]1976-we are only four miles from [the coast]1977-the coast . "[31-poirot]

" [The coast]1977-the coast ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , puzzled . " What has that got to do with it ? "[0-i]

" Yes . "[31-poirot]

" But but [I]31-poirot thought [you]0-i thought so too ? "[31-poirot]

"[31-poirot]

" No , "[0-i] [I]0-i confessed , " [I]0-i never thought of such a thing . "[0-i]

" [The blackguard]1992-the blackguard ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried indignantly .

But [I]0-i could not look at it in [Poirot]31-poirot 's philosophical way .

" And this is [the man with whom [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish has been wandering about all over [the country]1465-the country]1995-the man with whom mrs. cavendish has been wandering about all over the country ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried indignantly .

" Yes . [I]31-poirot should fancy [he]46-dr. bauerstein had found [her]33-mrs. cavendish very useful , "[31-poirot] remarked [Poirot]31-poirot . [My]0-i pleasing thoughts were interrupted by the sudden entrance of [Miss Howard]40-miss howard . [She]804-she glanced round hastily to make sure there was [no one else]1929-no one else in [the room]230-the room , and quickly produced an old sheet of brown paper . This [she]804-she handed to [Poirot]31-poirot , murmuring as [she]804-she did so the cryptic words :

" On top of [the wardrobe]2000-the wardrobe . "[804-she] Then [she]804-she hurriedly left [the room]230-the room .

[Poirot]31-poirot unfolded the sheet of paper eagerly , and uttered an exclamation of satisfaction . [He]31-poirot spread it out on the table .

" Come here , [Hastings]40-miss howard . Now tell [me]804-she , what is that initial J. or L. ? "[804-she]

It was a medium sized sheet of paper , rather dusty , as though it had lain by for some time . But it was the label that was attracting [Poirot]31-poirot 's attention . At the top , it bore the printed stamp of [Messrs. Parkson]110-parkson 's , [the well - known theatrical costumiers]808-the well - known theatrical costumiers , and it was addressed to " ( the debatable initial ) [Cavendish]2001-cavendish , Esq . , [Styles Court]5-styles court , [Styles St. Mary]6-styles st. mary , [Essex]3-essex . "[808-the well - known theatrical costumiers]

" It might be T. , or it might be L. , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , after studying the thing for a minute or two . " It certainly is n't a J. "[0-i]

" Good , "[31-poirot] replied [Poirot]31-poirot , folding up the paper again . " [I]31-poirot , also , am of [your]40-miss howard way of thinking . It is an L. , depend upon it ! "[31-poirot]

" Where did it come from ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked curiously . " Is it important ? "[0-i]

" Moderately so . It confirms a surmise of [mine]31-poirot . Having deduced its existence , [I]0-i set [Miss Howard]40-miss howard to search for it , and , as [you]40-miss howard see , [she]2002-she has been successful . "[0-i]

" What did [she]2002-she mean by On the top of the wardrobe ' ? "[0-i]

" [She]2002-she meant , "[31-poirot] replied [Poirot]31-poirot promptly , " that [she]2002-she found it on top of a wardrobe . "[31-poirot]

" A funny place for a piece of brown paper , "[0-i] [I]0-i mused .

" Not at all . The top of [a wardrobe]2003-a wardrobe is an excellent place for brown paper and cardboard boxes . [I]31-poirot have kept them [there]140-there [myself]31-poirot . Neatly arranged , there is nothing to offend the eye . "[31-poirot]

" [Poirot]31-poirot , "[0-i] [I]0-i asked earnestly , " have [you]31-poirot made up [your]31-poirot mind about this crime ? "[0-i]

" Yes that is to say , [I]64-dorcas believe [I]64-dorcas know how it was committed . "[64-dorcas]

" Ah ! "[0-i]

" Unfortunately , [I]64-dorcas have no proof beyond [my]64-dorcas surmise , unless "[64-dorcas] With sudden energy , [he]31-poirot caught [me]0-i by the arm , and whirled [me]0-i down [the hall]297-the hall , calling out in French in [his]31-poirot excitement : " [Mademoiselle Dorcas]64-dorcas , [Mademoiselle Dorcas]64-dorcas , _ un moment , s'il vous pla t ! _ "[31-poirot]

" Why , that there is altogether too much strychnine about this case . This is the third time [we]2066-we run up against it .
