CHAPTER XI .

THE CASE FOR THE PROSECUTION

The trial of [John Cavendish]32-john for the murder of [[his]32-john stepmother]1408-his stepmother took place two months later .

Of the intervening weeks [I]0-i will say little , but [my]0-i admiration and sympathy went out unfeignedly to [Mary Cavendish]41-mary . [She]41-mary ranged [herself]41-mary passionately on [[her]41-mary husband]203-her husband 's side , scorning the mere idea of [his]203-her husband guilt , and fought for [him]203-her husband tooth and nail .

[I]0-i expressed [my]0-i admiration to [Poirot]31-poirot , and [he]31-poirot nodded thoughtfully .

" Yes , [she]41-mary is of [those women who show at [their]2081-those women who show at their best in adversity best in adversity]2081-those women who show at their best in adversity . It brings out all that is sweetest and truest in [them]2081-those women who show at their best in adversity . [Her]41-mary pride and [her]41-mary jealousy have "[31-poirot]

" Jealousy ? "[0-i] [I]0-i queried .

" Yes . Have [you]31-poirot not realized that [she]41-mary is [an unusually jealous woman]2082-an unusually jealous woman ? As [I]31-poirot was saying , [her]41-mary pride and jealousy have been laid aside . [She]41-mary thinks of nothing but [[her]41-mary husband]203-her husband , and the terrible fate that is hanging over [him]203-her husband . "[31-poirot]

[He]31-poirot spoke very feelingly , and [I]0-i looked at [him]31-poirot earnestly , remembering that last afternoon , when [he]31-poirot had been deliberating whether or not to speak . With [his]31-poirot tenderness for " [a woman]772-a woman 's happiness , "[0-i] [I]0-i felt glad that the decision had been taken out of [his]31-poirot hands .

" Even now , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " [I]0-i can hardly believe it . [You]31-poirot see , up to the very last minute , [I]0-i thought it was [Lawrence]52-lawrence ! "[0-i]

[Poirot]31-poirot grinned .

" [I]0-i know [you]0-i did . "[0-i]

" But [John]32-john ! [[My]0-i old friend]1154-my old friend [John]32-john ! "[0-i]

" [Every murderer]2086-every murderer is probably [somebody 's old friend]2087-somebody 's old friend , "[31-poirot] observed [Poirot]31-poirot philosophically . " [You]0-i can not mix up sentiment and reason . "[31-poirot]

" [I]0-i must say [I]0-i think [you]31-poirot might have given [me]0-i a hint . "[0-i]

" Perhaps , _ mon ami _ , [I]31-poirot did not do so , just because [he]1154-my old friend _ was _ [[your]0-i old friend]2088-your old friend . "[31-poirot]

[I]0-i was rather disconcerted by this , remembering how [I]0-i had busily passed on to [John]32-john what [I]0-i believed to be [Poirot]31-poirot 's views concerning [Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein . [He]32-john , by the way , had been acquitted of the charge brought against [him]32-john . Nevertheless , although [he]32-john had been too clever for [them]835-them this time , and the charge of espionage could not be brought [home]132-home to [him]32-john , [his]32-john wings were pretty well clipped for the future .

[I]0-i asked [Poirot]31-poirot whether [he]31-poirot thought [John]32-john would be condemned . To [my]0-i intense surprise , [he]31-poirot replied that , on the contrary , [he]32-john was extremely likely to be acquitted .

" But , [Poirot]31-poirot "[0-i] [I]0-i protested .

" Oh , [[my]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , have [I]31-poirot not said to [you]129-my friend all along that [I]31-poirot have no proofs . " When did [you]31-poirot first suspect [John Cavendish]32-john ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , after a minute or two .

" No , indeed . "[0-i]

" No . "[0-i]

" What ? "[0-i]

[September]114-september found [us]839-us all in [London]12-london . [Mary]41-mary took [a house in [Kensington]25-kensington]840-a house in kensington , [Poirot]31-poirot being included in [the family party]841-the family party .

[I]0-i [myself]0-i had been given a job at [the War Office]842-the war office , so was able to see [them]843-them continually .

As the weeks went by , the state of [Poirot]31-poirot 's nerves grew worse and worse . That " last link "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot talked about was still lacking . Privately , [I]0-i hoped it might remain so , for what happiness could there be for [Mary]41-mary , if [John]32-john were not acquitted ?

On September 15th [John Cavendish]32-john appeared in [the dock]844-the dock at [the Old Bailey]845-the old bailey , charged with " The Wilful Murder of [Emily Agnes Inglethorp]115-emily agnes inglethorp , "[32-john] and pleaded " Not Guilty . "[117-mr. philips]

[Sir Ernest Heavywether]116-sir ernest , [the famous K.C.]846-the famous k.c. , had been engaged to defend [him]32-john .

[Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips , [K.C.]118-k.c. , opened the case for [the Crown]119-the crown .

The murder , [he]117-mr. philips said , was a most premeditated and cold - blooded one . It was neither more nor less than the deliberate poisoning of [a fond and trusting woman]847-a fond and trusting woman by [the stepson to whom [she]847-a fond and trusting woman had been more than [a mother]849-a mother]848-the stepson to whom she had been more than a mother . Ever since [his]117-mr. philips boyhood , [she]847-a fond and trusting woman had supported [him]117-mr. philips . [He]117-mr. philips and [[his]117-mr. philips wife]149-his wife had lived at [Styles Court]5-styles court in every luxury , surrounded by [her]847-a fond and trusting woman care and attention . [She]847-a fond and trusting woman had been [[their]851-their kind and generous benefactress]852-their kind and generous benefactress .

[He]117-mr. philips proposed to call [witnesses]1398-witnesses to show how [the prisoner]854-the prisoner , [a profligate and spendthrift]855-a profligate and spendthrift , had been at the end of [his]854-the prisoner financial tether , and had also been carrying on an intrigue with a certain [Mrs. Raikes]56-mrs. raikes , [[a neighbouring farmer]856-a neighbouring farmer 's wife]857-a neighbouring farmer 's wife . This having come to [[his]117-mr. philips stepmother]1408-his stepmother 's ears , [she]847-a fond and trusting woman taxed [him]117-mr. philips with it on the afternoon before [her]847-a fond and trusting woman death , and a quarrel ensued , part of which was overheard . On the previous day , [the prisoner]854-the prisoner had purchased strychnine at [[the village chemist]860-the village chemist 's shop]861-the village chemist 's shop , wearing a disguise by means of which [he]854-the prisoner hoped to throw the onus of the crime upon [another man to wit]862-another man to wit , [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's husband]863-mrs. inglethorp 's husband , of whom [he]117-mr. philips had been bitterly jealous . Luckily for [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp , [he]37-mr. inglethorp had been able to produce an unimpeachable alibi .

On the afternoon of July 17th , continued Counsel , immediately after the quarrel with [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp son]864-her son , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp made a new will . This will was found destroyed in the grate of [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp bedroom]1421-her bedroom the following morning , but evidence had come to light which showed that it had been drawn up in favour of [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband . [Deceased]120-deceased had already made a will in [his]120-deceased favour before [her]44-mrs. inglethorp marriage , but and [Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips wagged an expressive forefinger [the prisoner]854-the prisoner was not aware of that . What had induced [the deceased]565-the deceased to make a fresh will , with the old one still extant , [he]117-mr. philips could not say . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp was [an old lady]869-an old lady , and might possibly have forgotten [the former one]870-the former one ; or this seemed to [him]117-mr. philips more likely [she]44-mrs. inglethorp may have had an idea that it was revoked by [her]44-mrs. inglethorp marriage , as there had been some conversation on the subject . [Ladies]871-ladies were not always very well versed in legal knowledge . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp had , about a year before , executed a will in favour of [the prisoner]854-the prisoner . [He]117-mr. philips would call evidence to show that it was [the prisoner who ultimately handed [his]117-mr. philips stepmother]873-the prisoner who ultimately handed his stepmother [her]44-mrs. inglethorp coffee on the fatal night . Later in the evening , [he]117-mr. philips had sought admission to [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp room]1325-her room , on which occasion , no doubt , [he]117-mr. philips found an opportunity of destroying the will which , as far as [he]117-mr. philips knew , would render the one in [his]117-mr. philips favour valid .

[The prisoner]854-the prisoner had been arrested in consequence of the discovery , in [[his]854-the prisoner room]345-his room , by [Detective Inspector Japp]92-japp [a most brilliant officer of the identical phial of strychnine which had been sold at [the village chemist 's]1696-the village chemist 's to [the supposed Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp on the day before the murder]877-a most brilliant officer of the identical phial of strychnine which had been sold at the village chemist 's to the supposed mr. inglethorp on the day before the murder . It would be for [the jury]557-the jury to decide whether or not these damning facts constituted an overwhelming proof of [the prisoner]854-the prisoner 's guilt .

And , subtly implying that [a jury which did not so decide]881-a jury which did not so decide , was quite unthinkable , [Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips sat down and wiped [his]117-mr. philips forehead .

[The first witnesses for the prosecution]882-the first witnesses for the prosecution were mostly [those who had been called at the inquest]883-those who had been called at the inquest , the medical evidence being again taken first .

" [I]116-sir ernest take it , [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein , that strychnine , as a drug , acts quickly ? "[116-sir ernest]

[Mr. Mace]84-mr. mace identified the phial handed [him]84-mr. mace by [Counsel]885-counsel as that sold by [him]84-mr. mace to " [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . "[84-mr. mace] Pressed , [he]84-mr. mace admitted that [he]84-mr. mace only knew [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp by sight . [He]84-mr. mace had never spoken to [him]37-mr. inglethorp . [The witness]886-the witness was not cross - examined .

[Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp was called , and denied having purchased the poison . [He]37-mr. inglethorp also denied having quarrelled with [[his]37-mr. inglethorp wife]149-his wife . [Various witnesses]888-various witnesses testified to the accuracy of these statements .

[The gardeners]1527-the gardeners ' evidence , as to the witnessing of the will was taken , and then [Dorcas]64-dorcas was called .

[Dorcas]64-dorcas , faithful to [[her]64-dorcas " young gentlemen]2100-her " young gentlemen , "[64-dorcas] denied strenuously that it could have been [John]32-john 's voice [she]64-dorcas heard , and resolutely declared , in the teeth of everything , that it was [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp who had been in [the boudoir]301-the boudoir with [[her]64-dorcas mistress]553-her mistress . [He]37-mr. inglethorp knew only too well how useless [her]64-dorcas gallant defiance was , since it was not the object of the defence to deny this point . After various questions on other matters , [Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips asked :

" That is better . "[895-i]

[An assistant from [Parkson]110-parkson 's , [Theatrical Costumiers]122-theatrical costumiers]897-an assistant from parkson 's , theatrical costumiers , testified that on June 29th , [they]898-they had supplied a black beard to [Mr. L. Cavendish]123-mr. l. cavendish , as requested . It was ordered by letter , and a postal order was enclosed . No , [they]898-they had not kept the letter . All transactions were entered in [their]898-they books . [They]898-they had sent the beard , as directed , to " L. Cavendish , Esq . , [Styles Court]2112-styles court . "[898-they]

[Sir Ernest Heavywether]116-sir ernest rose ponderously .

" Where was the letter written from ? "[116-sir ernest]

" From [Styles Court]5-styles court . "[898-they]

" The same address to which [you]1184-sir sent the parcel ? "[116-sir ernest]

" Yes . "[898-they]

" And the letter came from there ? "[116-sir ernest]

" Yes . "[898-they]

Like a beast of prey , [Heavywether]116-sir ernest fell upon [him]116-sir ernest :

" How do [you]1184-sir know ? "[898-they]

" No but "[116-sir ernest]

" Ah , [you]1184-sir did _ not _ notice the postmark ! And yet [you]1184-sir affirm so confidently that it came from [Styles]4-styles . It might , in fact , have been any postmark ? "[898-they]

" Y es . "[116-sir ernest]

" In fact , the letter , though written on stamped notepaper , might have been posted from anywhere ? From [Wales]27-wales , for instance ? "[898-they]

[The witness]886-the witness admitted that such might be the case , and [Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest signified that [he]116-sir ernest was satisfied .

[Elizabeth Wells]124-elizabeth wells , [second housemaid at Styles]900-second housemaid at styles , stated that after [she]124-elizabeth wells had gone to bed [she]124-elizabeth wells remembered that [she]124-elizabeth wells had bolted the front door , instead of leaving it on the latch as [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp had requested . [She]124-elizabeth wells had accordingly gone [downstairs]356-downstairs again to rectify [her]124-elizabeth wells error . Hearing a slight noise in [the West wing]902-the west wing , [she]124-elizabeth wells had peeped along [the passage]334-the passage , and had seen [Mr. John Cavendish]32-john knocking at [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's door .

[Sir Ernest Heavywether]116-sir ernest made short work of [her]124-elizabeth wells , and under [his]116-sir ernest unmerciful bullying [she]124-elizabeth wells contradicted [herself]124-elizabeth wells hopelessly , and [Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest sat down again with a satisfied smile on [his]116-sir ernest face .

But [I]0-i [myself]0-i was puzzled , and as soon as [I]0-i was alone with [Poirot]31-poirot [I]0-i asked [him]31-poirot what [he]31-poirot thought [Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest was driving at .

[Detective - inspector]909-detective - inspector [Japp]92-japp was [the first witness called when the trial]910-the first witness called when the trial was reopened , and gave [his]92-japp evidence succinctly and briefly . After relating the earlier events , [he]92-japp proceeded :

" Acting on information received , [Superintendent Summerhaye]94-summerhaye and [myself]92-japp searched [[the prisoner]854-the prisoner 's room]2119-the prisoner 's room , during [his]116-sir ernest temporary absence from [the house]1063-the house . "[92-japp]

The phial was that already recognized by [[the chemist]1698-the chemist 's assistant]1699-the chemist 's assistant , a tiny bottle of blue glass , containing a few grains of a white crystalline powder , and labelled : " Strychnine Hydro - chloride . POISON . "[92-japp]

A fresh piece of evidence discovered by [the detectives]1690-the detectives since the police court proceedings was a long , almost new piece of blotting - paper . It had been found in [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's cheque book , and on being reversed at a mirror , showed clearly the words : " . . . erything of which [I]92-japp die possessed [I]92-japp leave to [[my]92-japp beloved husband]2122-my beloved husband [Alfred Ing]125-alfred ing ... [Japp]92-japp then produced the charred fragment of paper recovered from the grate , and this , with the discovery of the beard in [the attic]725-the attic , completed [his]92-japp evidence .

But [Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest 's cross - examination was yet to come .

" What day was it when [you]92-japp searched [[the prisoner]854-the prisoner 's room]2119-the prisoner 's room ? "[918-a woman of her pride]

" Yes . "[854-the prisoner]

" [You]92-japp found these two objects , [you]92-japp say , in the chest of drawers . Was the drawer unlocked ? "[918-a woman of her pride]

" Yes . "[854-the prisoner]

[Lawrence Cavendish]52-lawrence was then put into the box . The bullying manner was highly efficacious with a nervous disposition .

This bit of cross - examination had caused great excitement in [court]925-court . The heads of [the many fashionably attired women present]926-the many fashionably attired women present were busily laid together , and [their]926-the many fashionably attired women present whispers became so loud that [the judge]920-the judge angrily threatened to have the court cleared if there was not immediate silence .

There was little more evidence . [The hand - writing experts]928-the hand - writing experts were called upon for [their]928-the hand - writing experts opinion of the signature of " [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp "[928-the hand - writing experts] in [the chemist]1698-the chemist 's poison register . [They]928-the hand - writing experts all declared unanimously that it was certainly not [his]930-his hand - writing , and gave it as [their]928-the hand - writing experts view that it might be that of [the prisoner disguised]931-the prisoner disguised . Cross - examined , [they]928-the hand - writing experts admitted that it might be [the prisoner]854-the prisoner 's hand - writing cleverly counterfeited .

[Sir Ernest Heavywether]116-sir ernest 's speech in opening the case for the defence was not a long one , but it was backed by the full force of [his]116-sir ernest emphatic manner . Never , [he]116-sir ernest said , in the course of [his]116-sir ernest long experience , had [he]116-sir ernest known a charge of murder rest on slighter evidence . Not only was it entirely circumstantial , but the greater part of it was practically unproved . Let [them]928-the hand - writing experts take the testimony [they]928-the hand - writing experts had heard and sift it impartially . The strychnine had been found in a drawer in [[the prisoner]854-the prisoner 's room]2119-the prisoner 's room . That drawer was an unlocked one , as [he]116-sir ernest had pointed out , and [he]116-sir ernest submitted that there was no evidence to prove that it was [the prisoner who had concealed the poison there]935-the prisoner who had concealed the poison there . It was , in fact , a wicked and malicious attempt on the part of [some third person]936-some third person to fix the crime on [the prisoner]854-the prisoner . [The prosecution]938-the prosecution had been unable to produce a shred of evidence in support of [their]938-the prosecution contention that it was [the prisoner who ordered the black beard from [[Parkson]110-parkson 's]940-parkson 's]939-the prisoner who ordered the black beard from parkson 's . The quarrel which had taken place between [prisoner]941-prisoner and [[his]941-prisoner stepmother]1408-his stepmother was freely admitted , but both it and [his]941-prisoner financial embarrassments had been grossly exaggerated .

[[His]116-sir ernest learned friend]943-his learned friend [Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest nodded carelessly at [Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips had stated that if [the prisoner]854-the prisoner were [an innocent man]945-an innocent man , [he]116-sir ernest would have come forward at the inquest to explain that it was [he]854-the prisoner , and not [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp , who had been [the participator in the quarrel]946-the participator in the quarrel . [He]116-sir ernest thought the facts had been misrepresented . What had actually occurred was this . [The prisoner]854-the prisoner , returning to [the house]1063-the house on Tuesday evening , had been authoritatively told that there had been a violent quarrel between [Mr.]949-mr. and [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp . No suspicion had entered [the prisoner]854-the prisoner 's head that [anyone]1030-anyone could possibly have mistaken [his]854-the prisoner voice for that of [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . [He]854-the prisoner naturally concluded that [[his]854-the prisoner stepmother]1408-his stepmother had had two quarrels .

[The prosecution]938-the prosecution averred that on Monday , July 16th , [the prisoner]854-the prisoner had entered [[the chemist]1698-the chemist 's shop in [the village]1124-the village]956-the chemist 's shop in the village , disguised as [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . [The prisoner]854-the prisoner , on the contrary , was at that time at [a lonely spot called [Marston 's Spinney]28-marston 's spinney]959-a lonely spot called marston 's spinney , where [he]854-the prisoner had been summoned by an anonymous note , couched in blackmailing terms , and threatening to reveal certain matters to [[his]854-the prisoner wife]149-his wife unless [he]854-the prisoner complied with its demands . [The prisoner]854-the prisoner had , accordingly , gone to the appointed spot , and after waiting there vainly for half an hour had returned [home]132-home . Unfortunately , [he]854-the prisoner had met with [no one on the way there]963-no one on the way there or back who could vouch for the truth of [his]854-the prisoner story , but luckily [he]854-the prisoner had kept the note , and it would be produced as evidence .

As for the statement relating to the destruction of the will , [the prisoner]854-the prisoner had formerly practised at [the Bar]965-the bar , and was perfectly well aware that the will made in [his]854-the prisoner favour a year before was automatically revoked by [[his]854-the prisoner stepmother]1408-his stepmother 's remarriage . [He]854-the prisoner would call evidence to show who did destroy the will , and it was possible that that might open up quite a new view of the case .

Finally , [he]854-the prisoner would point out to [the jury]557-the jury that there was evidence against [other people]165-other people besides [John Cavendish]32-john . [He]854-the prisoner would direct [their]557-the jury attention to the fact that the evidence against [Mr. Lawrence Cavendish]52-lawrence was quite as strong , if not stronger than that against [[his]854-the prisoner brother]277-his brother .

[He]854-the prisoner would now call [the prisoner]854-the prisoner .

[John]32-john acquitted [himself]32-john well in the witness - box . Under [Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest 's skilful handling , [he]32-john told [his]32-john tale credibly and well . The anonymous note received by [him]116-sir ernest was produced , and handed to [the jury]557-the jury to examine . The readiness with which [he]116-sir ernest admitted [his]116-sir ernest financial difficulties , and the disagreement with [[his]116-sir ernest stepmother]1408-his stepmother , lent value to [his]116-sir ernest denials .

At the close of [his]116-sir ernest examination , [he]116-sir ernest paused , and said :

" [I]116-sir ernest should like to make one thing clear . [I]116-sir ernest utterly reject and disapprove of [Sir Ernest Heavywether]116-sir ernest 's insinuations against [[my]116-sir ernest brother]1382-my brother . [[My]116-sir ernest brother]1382-my brother , [I]116-sir ernest am convinced , had no more to do with the crime than [I]116-sir ernest have . "[116-sir ernest]

[Sir Ernest]116-sir ernest merely smiled , and noted with a sharp eye that [John]32-john 's protest had produced a very favourable impression on [the jury]557-the jury .

Then the cross - examination began .

" [I]557-the jury understand [you]32-john to say that it never entered [your]32-john head that [the witnesses at the inquest]2146-the witnesses at the inquest could possibly have mistaken [your]32-john voice for that of [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp . Is not that very surprising ? "[557-the jury]

" No , [I]557-the jury do n't think so . [I]557-the jury was told there had been a quarrel between [[my]557-the jury mother]1050-my mother and [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp , and it never occurred to [me]557-the jury that such was not really the case . "[557-the jury]

" Not when [the servant Dorcas]2148-the servant dorcas repeated certain fragments of the conversation fragments which [you]32-john must have recognized ? "[557-the jury]

" [I]557-the jury did not recognize them . "[557-the jury]

" [Your]32-john memory must be unusually short ! "[557-the jury]

" No , but [we]2149-we were both angry , and , [I]557-the jury think , said more than [we]2149-we meant . [I]557-the jury paid very little attention to [[my]557-the jury mother]1050-my mother 's actual words . "[557-the jury]

[Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips ' incredulous sniff was a triumph of forensic skill . [He]117-mr. philips passed on to the subject of the note .

" [You]32-john have produced this note very opportunely . Tell [me]117-mr. philips , is there nothing familiar about the hand - writing of it ? "[117-mr. philips]

" Not that [I]117-mr. philips know of . "[117-mr. philips]

" Do [you]32-john not think that it bears a marked resemblance to [your]32-john own hand - writing carelessly disguised ? "[117-mr. philips]

" No , [I]117-mr. philips do not think so . "[117-mr. philips]

" [I]117-mr. philips put it to [you]32-john that it is [your]32-john own hand - writing ! "[117-mr. philips]

" No . "[117-mr. philips]

" [I]117-mr. philips put it to [you]32-john that , anxious to prove an alibi , [you]32-john conceived the idea of a fictitious and rather incredible appointment , and wrote this note [yourself]32-john in order to bear out [your]32-john statement ! "[117-mr. philips]

" No . "[117-mr. philips]

" Is it not a fact that , at the time [you]32-john claim to have been waiting about at [a solitary and unfrequented spot]2151-a solitary and unfrequented spot , [you]32-john were really in [[the chemist]1698-the chemist 's shop in [Styles St. Mary]6-styles st. mary , where [you]32-john purchased strychnine in the name of [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp]2153-the chemist 's shop in styles st. mary , where you purchased strychnine in the name of alfred inglethorp ? "[117-mr. philips]

" No , that is a lie . "[117-mr. philips]

" [I]117-mr. philips put it to [you]32-john that , wearing a suit of [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp 's clothes , with a black beard trimmed to resemble [his]37-mr. inglethorp , [you]32-john were there and signed the register in [his]37-mr. inglethorp name ! "[117-mr. philips]

" That is absolutely untrue . "[117-mr. philips]

" Then [I]117-mr. philips will leave the remarkable similarity of hand - writing between the note , the register , and [your]32-john own , to the consideration of [the jury]557-the jury , "[117-mr. philips] said [Mr. Philips]117-mr. philips , and sat down with the air of [a man who has done [his]974-a man who has done his duty , but who was nevertheless horrified by such deliberate perjury duty , but who was nevertheless horrified by such deliberate perjury]974-a man who has done his duty , but who was nevertheless horrified by such deliberate perjury .

After this , as it was growing late , the case was adjourned till Monday .

[Poirot]31-poirot , [I]0-i noticed , was looking profoundly discouraged . [He]31-poirot had that little frown between the eyes that [I]0-i knew so well .

" What is it , [Poirot]31-poirot ? "[0-i] [I]0-i inquired .

" Ah , _ mon ami _ , things are going badly , badly . "[975-we]

In spite of [myself]0-i , [my]0-i heart gave a leap of relief . Evidently there was a likelihood of [John Cavendish]32-john being acquitted .

When [we]975-we reached [the house]1063-the house , [[my]0-i little friend]977-my little friend waved aside [Mary]56-mrs. raikes 's offer of tea .

" No , [I]977-my little friend thank [you]0-i , [madame]1889-madame . [I]977-my little friend will mount to [[my]977-my little friend room]213-my room . "[977-my little friend]

[I]0-i followed [him]977-my little friend . Still frowning , [he]977-my little friend went across to the desk and took out a small pack of patience cards . Then [he]977-my little friend drew up a chair to the table , and , to [my]0-i utter amazement , began solemnly to build [card houses]978-card houses !

[My]0-i jaw dropped involuntarily , and [he]977-my little friend said at once :

" No , _ mon ami _ , [I]977-my little friend am not in [my]977-my little friend second childhood ! [I]977-my little friend steady [my]977-my little friend nerves , that is all . This employment requires precision of the fingers . With precision of the fingers goes precision of the brain . And never have [I]977-my little friend needed that more than now ! "[977-my little friend]

" What is the trouble ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

With a great thump on the table , [Poirot]31-poirot demolished [his]31-poirot carefully built up edifice .

" It is this , _ mon ami ! _ That [I]977-my little friend can build card houses seven stories high , but [I]977-my little friend can not "[977-my little friend] thump " find "[977-my little friend] thump " that last link of which [I]977-my little friend spoke to [you]0-i . "[977-my little friend]

[I]0-i could not quite tell what to say , so [I]0-i held [my]0-i peace , and [he]977-my little friend began slowly building up the cards again , speaking in jerks as [he]977-my little friend did so .

" It is done so ! By placing one card on another with mathematical precision ! "[977-my little friend]

[I]0-i watched the card house rising under [his]977-my little friend hands , story by story . [He]977-my little friend never hesitated or faltered . It was really almost like a conjuring trick .

" What a steady hand [you]977-my little friend 've got , "[0-i] [I]0-i remarked . " [I]0-i believe [I]0-i 've only seen [your]977-my little friend hand shake once . "[0-i]

" On an occasion when [I]31-poirot was enraged , without doubt , "[31-poirot] observed [Poirot]31-poirot , with great placidity .

" Yes indeed ! [You]977-my little friend were in a towering rage . Do [you]977-my little friend remember ? It was when [you]977-my little friend discovered that the lock of the despatch - case in [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's bedroom]1314-mrs. inglethorp 's bedroom had been forced . [You]977-my little friend stood by the mantelpiece , twiddling the things on it in [your]977-my little friend usual fashion , and [your]977-my little friend hand shook like a leaf ! [I]0-i must say "[0-i]

But [I]0-i stopped suddenly . For [Poirot]31-poirot , uttering a hoarse and inarticulate cry , again annihilated [his]31-poirot masterpiece of cards , and putting [his]31-poirot hands over [his]31-poirot eyes swayed backwards and forwards , apparently suffering the keenest agony .

" Good heavens , [Poirot]31-poirot ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried . " What is the matter ? Are [you]977-my little friend taken ill ? "[0-i]

" No , no , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot gasped . " It is it is that [I]31-poirot have an idea ! "[31-poirot]

" Oh ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed , much relieved . " One of [your]31-poirot little ideas ' ? "[0-i]

" Ah , _ ma foi _ , no ! "[31-poirot] replied [Poirot]31-poirot frankly . " This time it is an idea gigantic ! Stupendous ! And [you]0-i _ [you]0-i _ , [[my]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , have given it to [me]31-poirot ! "[31-poirot]

Suddenly clasping [me]0-i in [his]31-poirot arms , [he]31-poirot kissed [me]0-i warmly on both cheeks , and before [I]0-i had recovered from [my]0-i surprise ran headlong from [the room]230-the room .

[Mary Cavendish]41-mary entered at that moment .

" What _ is _ the matter with [Monsieur Poirot]31-poirot ? [He]31-poirot rushed past [me]31-poirot crying out : [A garage]2159-a garage ! ' And , before [I]31-poirot could answer , [he]31-poirot had dashed out into [the street]538-the street . "[31-poirot]

[I]0-i hurried to the window . True enough , there [he]31-poirot was , tearing down [the street]538-the street , hatless , and gesticulating as [he]31-poirot went . [I]0-i turned to [Mary]41-mary with a gesture of despair .

" [He]31-poirot 'll be stopped by [a policeman]2163-a policeman in another minute . There [he]31-poirot goes , round the corner ! "[31-poirot]

[Our]981-us eyes met , and [we]981-us stared helplessly at [one another]517-one another .

" What can be the matter ? "[31-poirot]

[I]0-i shook [my]0-i head .

" [I]31-poirot do n't know . [He]31-poirot was building [card houses]978-card houses , when suddenly [he]31-poirot said [he]31-poirot had an idea , and rushed off as [you]41-mary saw . "[31-poirot]

" Well , "[41-mary] said [Mary]41-mary , " [I]41-mary expect [he]31-poirot will be back before dinner . "[41-mary]

But night fell , and [Poirot]31-poirot had not returned .

CHAPTER XII . [THE LAST LINK

Poirot]127-the last link poirot 's abrupt departure had intrigued [us]981-us all greatly . Sunday morning wore away , and still [he]31-poirot did not reappear . But about three o'clock a ferocious and prolonged hooting outside drove [us]981-us to the window , to see [Poirot]31-poirot alighting from [a car]1795-a car , accompanied by [Japp]92-japp and [Summerhaye]94-summerhaye . [The little man]411-the little man was transformed . [He]411-the little man radiated an absurd complacency . [He]411-the little man bowed with exaggerated respect to [Mary Cavendish]41-mary .

" [Madame]1889-madame , [I]411-the little man have [your]1889-madame permission to hold a little _ r union _ in [the _ salon _]2166-the _ salon _ ? It is necessary for [everyone]1075-everyone to attend . "[411-the little man]

[Mary]41-mary smiled sadly .

" [You]31-poirot know , [Monsieur Poirot]31-poirot , that [you]31-poirot have _ carte blanche _ in every way . "[411-the little man]

" [You]31-poirot are too amiable , [madame]1889-madame . "[41-mary]

Still beaming , [Poirot]31-poirot marshalled [us]985-us all into [the drawing - room]310-the drawing - room , bringing forward chairs as [he]31-poirot did so .

" [Miss Howard]40-miss howard [here]1157-here . [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia . [Monsieur Lawrence]34-monsieur lawrence . [The good Dorcas]64-dorcas . And [Annie]67-annie . _ Bien ! _ [We]985-us must delay [our]985-us proceedings a few minutes until [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp arrives . [I]41-mary have sent [him]37-mr. inglethorp a note . "[41-mary]

[Miss Howard]40-miss howard rose immediately from [her]987-her seat .

" If [that man]1115-that man comes into [the house]1063-the house , [I]41-mary leave [it]2172-it ! "[41-mary]

" No , no ! "[31-poirot] [Poirot]31-poirot went up to [her]987-her and pleaded in a low voice .

Finally [Miss Howard]40-miss howard consented to return to [her]987-her chair . A few minutes later [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp entered [the room]230-the room .

[The company]202-the company once assembled , [Poirot]31-poirot rose from [his]31-poirot seat with the air of [a popular lecturer]990-a popular lecturer , and bowed politely to [[his]31-poirot audience]991-his audience .

" _ Messieurs , mesdames _ , as [you]2173-you all know , [I]202-the company was called in by [Monsieur John Cavendish]32-john to investigate this case . [I]202-the company at once examined [the bedroom of [the deceased]565-the deceased which , by the advice of [the doctors]388-the doctors]2174-the bedroom of the deceased which , by the advice of the doctors , had been kept locked , and was consequently exactly as [it]2174-the bedroom of the deceased which , by the advice of the doctors had been when the tragedy occurred . [I]202-the company found : first , a fragment of green material ; second , a stain on the carpet near the window , still damp ; thirdly , an empty box of bromide powders .[202-the company]

" To take the fragment of green material first , [I]202-the company found it caught in the bolt of the communicating door between [that room]2177-that room and [the adjoining one occupied by [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia]2178-the adjoining one occupied by mademoiselle cynthia . [I]202-the company handed the fragment over to [the police who did not consider it of much importance]2179-the police who did not consider it of much importance . Nor did [they]2179-the police who did not consider it of much importance recognize it for what it was a piece torn from a green land armlet . "[202-the company]

There was a little stir of excitement .

" Now there was only [one person at [Styles]4-styles who worked on [the land]1045-the land [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish]2180-one person at styles who worked on the land mrs. cavendish . Therefore it must have been [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish who entered [[the deceased]565-the deceased 's room]2183-the deceased 's room through the door communicating with [[Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia 's room]2184-mademoiselle cynthia 's room . "[202-the company]

" But that door was bolted on the inside ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried .

" When [I]202-the company examined [the room]230-the room , yes . But in the first place [we]2186-we have only [her]33-mrs. cavendish word for it , since it was [she]33-mrs. cavendish who tried that particular door and reported it fastened . In the ensuing confusion [she]33-mrs. cavendish would have had ample opportunity to shoot the bolt across . [I]202-the company took an early opportunity of verifying [my]202-the company conjectures . To begin with , the fragment corresponds exactly with a tear in [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish 's armlet . Also , at the inquest , [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish declared that [she]33-mrs. cavendish had heard , from [[her]33-mrs. cavendish own room]2187-her own room , the fall of the table by the bed . [I]202-the company took an early opportunity of testing that statement by stationing [[my]202-the company friend]129-my friend [Monsieur Hastings]35-hastings in [the left wing of [the building]212-the building]2189-the left wing of the building , just outside [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish 's door . [I]202-the company [myself]202-the company , in company with [the police]1084-the police , went to [[the deceased]565-the deceased 's room]2183-the deceased 's room , and whilst [there]140-there [I]202-the company , apparently accidentally , knocked over the table in question , but found that , as [I]202-the company had expected , [Monsieur Hastings]35-hastings had heard no sound at all . This confirmed [my]202-the company belief that [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish was not speaking the truth when [she]33-mrs. cavendish declared that [she]33-mrs. cavendish had been dressing in [[her]33-mrs. cavendish room]1325-her room at the time of the tragedy . In fact , [I]202-the company was convinced that , far from having been in [[her]33-mrs. cavendish own room]2187-her own room , [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish was actually in [the deceased 's room]2183-the deceased 's room when the alarm was given . "[202-the company]

[I]0-i shot a quick glance at [Mary]41-mary . [She]41-mary was very pale , but smiling .

" [I]992-i proceeded to reason on that assumption . [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish is in [[[her]33-mrs. cavendish mother - in - law]408-her mother - in - law 's room]2199-her mother - in - law 's room . [We]2200-we will say that [she]33-mrs. cavendish is seeking for something and has not yet found it . Suddenly [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp awakens and is seized with an alarming paroxysm . [She]33-mrs. cavendish flings out [her]33-mrs. cavendish arm , overturning the bed table , and then pulls desperately at the bell . [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish , startled , drops [her]33-mrs. cavendish candle , scattering the grease on the carpet . [She]33-mrs. cavendish picks it up , and retreats quickly to [[Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia 's room]2184-mademoiselle cynthia 's room , closing the door behind [her]33-mrs. cavendish . [She]33-mrs. cavendish hurries out into [the passage]334-the passage , for [the servants]331-the servants must not find [her]33-mrs. cavendish where [she]33-mrs. cavendish is . But it is too late ! Already footsteps are echoing along the gallery which connects [the two wings]2204-the two wings . What can [she]33-mrs. cavendish do ? Quick as thought , [she]33-mrs. cavendish hurries back to [[the young girl]2205-the young girl 's room]2206-the young girl 's room , and starts shaking [her]2205-the young girl awake . [The hastily aroused household]2207-the hastily aroused household come trooping down [the passage]334-the passage . [They]2207-the hastily aroused household are all busily battering at [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's door . It occurs to [nobody]693-nobody that [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish has not arrived with the rest , but and this is significant [I]992-i can find [no one who saw [her]33-mrs. cavendish come from [the other wing]1772-the other wing]2210-no one who saw her come from the other wing . "[992-i] [He]992-i looked at [Mary Cavendish]41-mary . " Am [I]992-i right , [madame]1889-madame ? "[992-i]

[She]41-mary bowed [her]41-mary head .

" Quite right , [monsieur]1402-monsieur . [You]1402-monsieur understand that , if [I]41-mary had thought [I]41-mary would do [[my]41-mary husband]1072-my husband any good by revealing these facts , [I]41-mary would have done so . But it did not seem to [me]41-mary to bear upon the question of [his]1072-my husband guilt or innocence . "[41-mary]

" In a sense , that is correct , [madame]1889-madame . But it cleared [my]41-mary mind of many misconceptions , and left [me]41-mary free to see other facts in their true significance . "[41-mary]

" The will ! "[34-monsieur lawrence] cried [Lawrence]34-monsieur lawrence . " Then it was [you]41-mary , [Mary]41-mary , who destroyed the will ? "[34-monsieur lawrence]

[She]41-mary shook [her]41-mary head , and [Poirot]31-poirot shook [his]31-poirot also .

" No , "[31-poirot] [he]31-poirot said quietly . " There is only [one person who could possibly have destroyed that will [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp [herself]44-mrs. inglethorp]2216-one person who could possibly have destroyed that will mrs. inglethorp herself ! "[31-poirot]

" Impossible ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed . " [She]44-mrs. inglethorp had only made it out that very afternoon ! "[0-i]

" Nevertheless , _ mon ami _ , it was [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp . Because , in no other way can [you]0-i account for the fact that , on one of the hottest days of the year , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp ordered a fire to be lighted in [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp room]1325-her room . "[31-poirot]

[I]0-i gave a gasp . What idiots [we]993-we had been never to think of that fire as being incongruous ! [Poirot]31-poirot was continuing :

" The temperature on that day , [messieurs]1743-messieurs , was 80 degrees in the shade . Yet [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp ordered a fire ! Why ? Because [she]44-mrs. inglethorp wished to destroy something , and could think of no other way . [You]0-i will remember that , in consequence of the War economics practiced at [Styles]4-styles , no waste paper was thrown away . There was therefore no means of destroying a thick document such as a will . The moment [I]31-poirot heard of a fire being lighted in [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's room]433-mrs. inglethorp 's room , [I]31-poirot leaped to the conclusion that it was to destroy some important document possibly a will . So the discovery of the charred fragment in the grate was no surprise to [me]31-poirot . [I]31-poirot did not , of course , know at the time that the will in question had only been made this afternoon , and [I]31-poirot will admit that , when [I]31-poirot learnt that fact , [I]31-poirot fell into a grievous error . [I]31-poirot came to the conclusion that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's determination to destroy [her]44-mrs. inglethorp will arose as a direct consequence of the quarrel [she]44-mrs. inglethorp had that afternoon , and that therefore the quarrel took place after , and not before the making of the will .[31-poirot]

" Here , as [we]993-we know , [I]0-i was wrong , and [I]0-i was forced to abandon that idea . [I]0-i faced the problem from a new standpoint . Now , at four o'clock , [Dorcas]64-dorcas overheard [[her]64-dorcas mistress]553-her mistress saying angrily : [You]64-dorcas need not think that any fear of publicity , or scandal between [husband]1264-husband and [wife]1265-wife will deter [me]0-i . "[0-i] [I]0-i conjectured , and conjectured rightly , that these words were addressed , not to [[her]994-i husband]203-her husband , but to [Mr. John Cavendish]32-john . At five o'clock , an hour later , [she]994-i uses almost the same words , but the standpoint is different . [She]994-i admits to [Dorcas]64-dorcas , [I]0-i do n't know what to do ; scandal between [husband]1264-husband and [wife]1265-wife is a dreadful thing . ' At four o'clock [she]994-i has been angry , but completely mistress of [herself]994-i . At five o'clock [she]994-i is in violent distress , and speaks of having had a great shock .

" Looking at the matter psychologically , [I]994-i drew one deduction which [I]994-i was convinced was correct . The second scandal ' [she]994-i spoke of was not the same as the first and it concerned [herself]994-i ![994-i]

" Let [us]2223-us reconstruct . At four o'clock , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp quarrels with [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp son]864-her son , and threatens to denounce [him]864-her son to [[his]864-her son wife]149-his wife who , by the way , overheard the greater part of the conversation . At four - thirty , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp , in consequence of a conversation on the validity of wills , makes a will in favour of [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband , which [the two gardeners]1530-the two gardeners witness . At five o'clock , [Dorcas]64-dorcas finds [[her]64-dorcas mistress]553-her mistress in a state of considerable agitation , with a slip of paper a letter , ' [Dorcas]64-dorcas thinks in [her]64-dorcas hand , and it is then that [she]64-dorcas orders the fire in [[her]64-dorcas room]1325-her room to be lighted . Presumably , then , between four - thirty and five o'clock , something has occurred to occasion a complete revolution of feeling , since [she]64-dorcas is now as anxious to destroy the will , as [she]64-dorcas was before to make it . What was that something ?[994-i]

" As far as [we]2230-we know , [she]64-dorcas was quite alone during that half - hour . [Nobody]693-nobody entered or left [that boudoir]2232-that boudoir . What then occasioned this sudden change of sentiment ?[994-i]

" [One]177-one can only guess , but [I]994-i believe [my]994-i guess to be correct . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp had no stamps in [her]44-mrs. inglethorp desk . [We]2230-we know this , because later [she]44-mrs. inglethorp asked [Dorcas]64-dorcas to bring [her]44-mrs. inglethorp some . Now in the opposite corner of [the room]230-the room stood [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband 's desk locked . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp was anxious to find some stamps , and , according to [my]994-i theory , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp tried [her]44-mrs. inglethorp own keys in the desk . That one of them fitted [I]994-i know . [She]44-mrs. inglethorp therefore opened the desk , and in searching for the stamps [she]44-mrs. inglethorp came across something else that slip of paper which [Dorcas]64-dorcas saw in [her]64-dorcas hand , and which assuredly was never meant for [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's eyes . On the other hand , [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish believed that the slip of paper to which [[her]33-mrs. cavendish mother - in - law]408-her mother - in - law clung so tenaciously was a written proof of [[her]33-mrs. cavendish own husband]1547-her own husband 's infidelity . [She]33-mrs. cavendish demanded it from [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp who assured [her]33-mrs. cavendish , quite truly , that it had nothing to do with that matter . [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish did not believe [her]33-mrs. cavendish . [She]33-mrs. cavendish thought that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp was shielding [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp stepson]1404-her stepson . Now [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish is [a very resolute woman]2239-a very resolute woman , and , behind [her]33-mrs. cavendish mask of reserve , [she]33-mrs. cavendish was madly jealous of [[her]33-mrs. cavendish husband]203-her husband . [She]33-mrs. cavendish determined to get hold of that paper at all costs , and in this resolution chance came to [her]33-mrs. cavendish aid . [She]33-mrs. cavendish happened to pick up the key of [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's despatch - case , which had been lost that morning . [She]33-mrs. cavendish knew that [[her]33-mrs. cavendish mother - in - law]408-her mother - in - law invariably kept all important papers in this particular case .[994-i]

" [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish , therefore , made [her]33-mrs. cavendish plans as only [a woman driven desperate through jealousy]2242-a woman driven desperate through jealousy could have done . Some time in the evening [she]33-mrs. cavendish unbolted the door leading into [[Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia 's room]2184-mademoiselle cynthia 's room . Possibly [she]33-mrs. cavendish applied oil to the hinges , for [I]994-i found that it opened quite noiselessly when [I]994-i tried it . [She]33-mrs. cavendish put off [her]33-mrs. cavendish project until the early hours of the morning as being safer , since [the servants]331-the servants were accustomed to hearing [her]33-mrs. cavendish move about [[her]33-mrs. cavendish room]1325-her room at that time . [She]33-mrs. cavendish dressed completely in [her]33-mrs. cavendish land kit , and made [her]33-mrs. cavendish way quietly through [[Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia 's room]2184-mademoiselle cynthia 's room into that of [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp . "[994-i]

[He]998-i paused a moment , and [Cynthia]38-cynthia interrupted :

" But [I]994-i should have woken up if [anyone]1030-anyone had come through [[my]994-i room]213-my room ? "[994-i]

" Not if [you]994-i were drugged , [mademoiselle]2249-mademoiselle . "[994-i]

" Drugged ? "[994-i]

" _ Mais , oui ! _ "[994-i]

" [You]38-cynthia remember "[998-i] [he]998-i addressed [us]999-us collectively again " that through all the tumult and noise next door [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia slept . That admitted of two possibilities . Either [her]38-cynthia sleep was feigned which [I]998-i did not believe or [her]38-cynthia unconsciousness was indeed by artificial means .[998-i]

" With this latter idea in [my]994-i mind , [I]994-i examined all the coffee - cups most carefully , remembering that it was [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish who had brought [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia [her]38-cynthia coffee the night before . [I]994-i took a sample from each cup , and had them analysed with no result . [I]994-i had counted the cups carefully , in the event of one having been removed . [Six persons]2250-six persons had taken coffee , and six cups were duly found . [I]994-i had to confess [myself]994-i mistaken .[994-i]

" Then [I]998-i discovered that [I]998-i had been guilty of a very grave oversight . Coffee had been brought in for [seven persons]2251-seven persons , not six , for [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein had been [there]140-there that evening . This changed the face of the whole affair , for there was now one cup missing . [The servants]331-the servants noticed nothing , since [Annie]67-annie , [the housemaid , who took in the coffee]2254-the housemaid , who took in the coffee , brought in seven cups , not knowing that [Mr. Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp never drank it , whereas [Dorcas]64-dorcas , who cleared [them]2250-six persons away the following morning , found six as usual or strictly speaking [she]64-dorcas found five , the sixth being the one found broken in [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's room]433-mrs. inglethorp 's room .[998-i]

" [I]994-i was confident that the missing cup was that of [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia . [I]994-i had an additional reason for that belief in the fact that all the cups found contained sugar , which [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia never took in [her]38-cynthia coffee . [My]994-i attention was attracted by the story of [Annie]67-annie about some salt ' on the tray of cocoa which [she]67-annie took every night to [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's room]433-mrs. inglethorp 's room . [I]994-i accordingly secured a sample of that cocoa , and sent it to be analysed . "[994-i]

" But that had already been done by [Dr. Bauerstein]46-dr. bauerstein , "[34-monsieur lawrence] said [Lawrence]34-monsieur lawrence quickly .

" Not exactly . [The analyst]2257-the analyst was asked by [him]46-dr. bauerstein to report whether strychnine was , or was not , present . [He]46-dr. bauerstein did not have it tested , as [I]998-i did , for a narcotic . "[998-i]

" For a narcotic ? "[994-i]

" Yes . Here is [the analyst]2257-the analyst 's report . [Mrs. Cavendish]33-mrs. cavendish administered a safe , but effectual , narcotic to both [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp and [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia . And it is possible that [she]33-mrs. cavendish had a _ mauvais quart d'heure _ in consequence ! Imagine [her]33-mrs. cavendish feelings when [[her]33-mrs. cavendish mother - in - law]408-her mother - in - law is suddenly taken ill and dies , and immediately after [she]33-mrs. cavendish hears the word Poison ' ! [She]33-mrs. cavendish has believed that the sleeping draught [she]33-mrs. cavendish administered was perfectly harmless , but there is no doubt that for one terrible moment [she]33-mrs. cavendish must have feared that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's death lay at [her]33-mrs. cavendish door . [She]33-mrs. cavendish is seized with panic , and under its influence [she]33-mrs. cavendish hurries [downstairs]356-downstairs , and quickly drops the coffee - cup and saucer used by [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia into a large brass vase , where it is discovered later by [Monsieur Lawrence]34-monsieur lawrence . The remains of the cocoa [she]33-mrs. cavendish dare not touch . Too many eyes are upon [her]33-mrs. cavendish . Guess at [her]33-mrs. cavendish relief when strychnine is mentioned , and [she]33-mrs. cavendish discovers that after all the tragedy is not [her]33-mrs. cavendish doing .[998-i]

" [We]2261-we are now able to account for the symptoms of strychnine poisoning being so long in making their appearance . A narcotic taken with strychnine will delay the action of the poison for some hours . "[994-i]

[Poirot]31-poirot paused . [Mary]41-mary looked up at [him]31-poirot , the colour slowly rising in [her]41-mary face .

" All [you]31-poirot have said is quite true , [Monsieur Poirot]31-poirot . It was the most awful hour of [my]31-poirot life . [I]31-poirot shall never forget it . But [you]31-poirot are wonderful . [I]31-poirot understand now "[31-poirot]

" What [I]41-mary meant when [I]41-mary told [you]31-poirot that [you]31-poirot could safely confess to [Papa Poirot]112-papa poirot , eh ? But [you]31-poirot would not trust [me]41-mary . "[41-mary]

" [I]34-monsieur lawrence see everything now , "[34-monsieur lawrence] said [Lawrence]34-monsieur lawrence . " The drugged cocoa , taken on top of the poisoned coffee , amply accounts for the delay . "[34-monsieur lawrence]

" Exactly . But was the coffee poisoned , or was it not ? [We]2261-we come to a little difficulty here , since [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp never drank it . "[41-mary]

" What ? "[34-monsieur lawrence] The cry of surprise was universal .

" No . [You]31-poirot will remember [my]41-mary speaking of a stain on the carpet in [[Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's room]433-mrs. inglethorp 's room ? There were some peculiar points about that stain . It was still damp , it exhaled a strong odour of coffee , and imbedded in the nap of the carpet [I]41-mary found some little splinters of china . What had happened was plain to [me]41-mary , for not two minutes before [I]41-mary had placed [my]41-mary little case on the table near the window , and the table , tilting up , had deposited it upon the floor on precisely the identical spot . In exactly the same way , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp had laid down [her]44-mrs. inglethorp cup of coffee on reaching [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp room]1325-her room the night before , and the treacherous table had played [her]44-mrs. inglethorp the same trick .[41-mary]

" What happened next is mere guess work on [my]31-poirot part , but [I]31-poirot should say that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp picked up the broken cup and placed it on the table by the bed . Feeling in need of a stimulant of some kind , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp heated up [her]44-mrs. inglethorp cocoa , and drank it off then and there . Now [we]2264-we are faced with a new problem . [We]2264-we know the cocoa contained no strychnine . The coffee was never drunk . Yet the strychnine must have been administered between seven and nine o'clock that evening . What third medium was there a medium so suitable for disguising the taste of strychnine that it is extraordinary [no one]1180-no one has thought of it ? "[31-poirot] [Poirot]31-poirot looked round [the room]230-the room , and then answered [himself]31-poirot impressively . " [Her]44-mrs. inglethorp medicine ! "[31-poirot]

" Do [you]41-mary mean that [the murderer]1087-the murderer introduced the strychnine into [her]44-mrs. inglethorp tonic ? "[0-i] [I]0-i cried .

" There was no need to introduce it . It was already there in the mixture . The strychnine that killed [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp was the identical strychnine prescribed by [Dr. Wilkins]66-dr. wilkins . To make that clear to [you]41-mary , [I]31-poirot will read [you]41-mary an extract from a book on dispensing which [I]31-poirot found in [the Dispensary of [the Red Cross Hospital]2054-the red cross hospital at [Tadminster]8-tadminster]2267-the dispensary of the red cross hospital at tadminster :[31-poirot]

" The following prescription has become famous in text books :[31-poirot]

Strychninae Sulph . . . . . . 1 gr .

Potass Bromide . . . . . . . 3vi

Aqua ad . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3viii

Fiat Mistura

_ This solution deposits in a few hours the greater part of the strychnine salt as an insoluble bromide in transparent crystals . [A lady in [England]13-england]1001-a lady in england lost [her]1001-a lady in england life by taking a similar mixture : the precipitated strychnine collected at the bottom , and in taking the last dose [she]1001-a lady in england swallowed nearly all of it ! _

" Now there was , of course , no bromide in [Dr. Wilkins]66-dr. wilkins ' prescription , but [you]41-mary will remember that [I]1001-a lady in england mentioned an empty box of bromide powders . One or two of those powders introduced into the full bottle of medicine would effectually precipitate the strychnine , as the book describes , and cause it to be taken in the last dose . [You]41-mary will learn later that [the person who usually poured out [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's medicine]2269-the person who usually poured out mrs. inglethorp 's medicine was always extremely careful not to shake the bottle , but to leave the sediment at the bottom of it undisturbed .[1001-a lady in england]

" Throughout the case , there have been evidences that the tragedy was intended to take place on Monday evening . On that day , [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's bell wire was neatly cut , and on Monday evening [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia was spending the night with [friends]135-friends , so that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp would have been quite alone in [the right wing]2271-the right wing , completely shut off from help of any kind , and would have died , in all probability , before medical aid could have been summoned . But in [her]44-mrs. inglethorp hurry to be in time for [the village]1124-the village entertainment [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp forgot to take [her]44-mrs. inglethorp medicine , and the next day [she]44-mrs. inglethorp lunched away from [home]132-home , so that the last and fatal dose was actually taken twenty - four hours later than had been anticipated by [the murderer]1087-the murderer ; and it is owing to that delay that the final proof the last link of the chain is now in [my]1001-a lady in england hands . "[1001-a lady in england]

Amid breathless excitement , [he]1002-he held out three thin strips of paper .

" A letter in [the murderer]1087-the murderer 's own hand - writing , _ mes amis ! _ Had it been a little clearer in its terms , it is possible that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp , warned in time , would have escaped . As it was , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp realized [her]44-mrs. inglethorp danger , but not the manner of it . "[1001-a lady in england]

In the deathly silence , [Poirot]31-poirot pieced together the slips of paper and , clearing [his]31-poirot throat , read :

[Dearest Evelyn]128-dearest evelyn :

[You]128-dearest evelyn will be anxious at hearing nothing . It is all right only it will be to - night instead of last night . [You]128-dearest evelyn understand . There 's a good time coming once [the old woman]1003-the old woman is dead and out of the way . [No one]1180-no one can possibly bring home the crime to [me]0-i . That idea of [yours]128-dearest evelyn about the bromides was a stroke of genius ! But [we]1005-we must be very circumspect . A false step '

" Here , [[my]1003-the old woman friends]1505-my friends , the letter breaks off . Doubtless [the writer]2277-the writer was interrupted ; but there can be no question as to [his]2277-the writer identity . [We]1005-we all know this hand - writing and "[1003-the old woman]

A howl that was almost a scream broke the silence .

" [You]128-dearest evelyn devil ! How did [you]128-dearest evelyn get it ? "[1003-the old woman]

A chair was overturned . [Poirot]31-poirot skipped nimbly aside . A quick movement on [his]31-poirot part , and [[his]31-poirot assailant]1006-his assailant fell with a crash .

" _ [Messieurs]2278-messieurs , mesdames _ , "[31-poirot] said [Poirot]31-poirot , with a flourish , " let [me]31-poirot introduce [you]128-dearest evelyn to [the murderer]1087-the murderer , [Mr. Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp ! "[31-poirot]

CHAPTER XIII . [POIROT]31-poirot EXPLAINS

" [Poirot]31-poirot , [[you]31-poirot old villain]2280-you old villain , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " [I]0-i 've half a mind to strangle [you]31-poirot ! What do [you]31-poirot mean by deceiving [me]0-i as [you]31-poirot have done ? "[0-i]

[We]1007-we were sitting in [the library]394-the library . Several hectic days lay behind [us]1007-we . In [the room below]1009-the room below , [John]32-john and [Mary]41-mary were together once more , while [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp and [Miss Howard]40-miss howard were in [custody]1010-custody . Now at last , [I]0-i had [Poirot]31-poirot to [myself]0-i , and could relieve [my]0-i still burning curiosity .

[Poirot]31-poirot did not answer [me]0-i for a moment , but at last [he]31-poirot said :

" [I]31-poirot did not deceive [you]0-i , _ mon ami _ . At most , [I]31-poirot permitted [you]0-i to deceive [yourself]0-i . "[31-poirot]

" Yes , but why ? "[31-poirot]

" Well , it is difficult to explain . [You]0-i see , [[my]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , [you]0-i have a nature so honest , and a countenance so transparent , that _ enfin _ , to conceal [your]0-i feelings is impossible ! " [I]31-poirot think that [I]31-poirot have more diplomacy than [you]0-i give [me]31-poirot credit for . "[31-poirot]

" [[My]31-poirot friend]129-my friend , "[31-poirot] besought [Poirot]31-poirot , " [I]31-poirot implore [you]0-i , do not enrage [yourself]0-i ! [Your]0-i help has been of the most invaluable . " Yes , but "[0-i]

" Do [you]31-poirot mean to say [you]31-poirot suspected [him]37-mr. inglethorp as long ago as that ? "[31-poirot]

" Yes . To begin with , whoever else might benefit by [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's death , [[her]44-mrs. inglethorp husband]203-her husband would benefit the most . "[31-poirot]

" Yes , yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said impatiently . " Go on . "[0-i]

" When did [you]0-i change [your]0-i mind ? "[0-i]

" When [I]31-poirot found that the more efforts [I]31-poirot made to clear [him]37-mr. inglethorp , the more efforts [he]37-mr. inglethorp made to get [himself]37-mr. inglethorp arrested . "[31-poirot]

" But why ? "[0-i]

" Simply this . If it had been [Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp who was carrying on an intrigue with [Mrs. Raikes]56-mrs. raikes , [his]37-mr. inglethorp silence was perfectly comprehensible . But , when [I]31-poirot discovered that it was known all over [the village]1124-the village that it was [[John]32-john who was attracted by [[the farmer]2294-the farmer 's pretty wife]2295-the farmer 's pretty wife]2293-john who was attracted by the farmer 's pretty wife , [his]37-mr. inglethorp silence bore quite a different interpretation . It was nonsense to pretend that [he]37-mr. inglethorp was afraid of the scandal , as no possible scandal could attach to [him]37-mr. inglethorp . This attitude of [his]37-mr. inglethorp gave [me]31-poirot furiously to think , and [I]31-poirot was slowly forced to the conclusion that [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp wanted to be arrested . _ Eh bien ! _ from that moment , [I]31-poirot was equally determined that [he]37-mr. inglethorp should not be arrested . "[31-poirot]

" Wait a minute . [I]0-i do n't see why [he]37-mr. inglethorp wished to be arrested ? "[0-i]

" Because , _ mon ami _ , it is the law of [[your]0-i country]2296-your country that [a man]196-a man once acquitted can never be tried again for the same offence . Aha ! but it was clever [his]37-mr. inglethorp idea ! Assuredly , [he]37-mr. inglethorp is [a man of method]1368-a man of method . See here , [he]37-mr. inglethorp knew that in [his]37-mr. inglethorp position [he]37-mr. inglethorp was bound to be suspected , so [he]37-mr. inglethorp conceived the exceedingly clever idea of preparing a lot of manufactured evidence against [himself]37-mr. inglethorp . [He]37-mr. inglethorp wished to be arrested . [He]37-mr. inglethorp would then produce [his]37-mr. inglethorp irreproachable alibi and , hey presto , [he]37-mr. inglethorp was safe for life ! "[31-poirot]

" But [I]0-i still do n't see how [he]37-mr. inglethorp managed to prove [his]37-mr. inglethorp alibi , and yet go to [the chemist 's shop]1554-the chemist 's shop ? "[0-i]

[Poirot]31-poirot stared at [me]0-i in surprise .

" Is it possible ? [[My]31-poirot poor friend]2300-my poor friend ! [You]2300-my poor friend have not yet realized that it was [Miss Howard]40-miss howard who went to [the chemist 's shop]1554-the chemist 's shop ? "[31-poirot]

" [Miss Howard]40-miss howard ? "[31-poirot]

" But , certainly . Who else ? It was most easy for [her]2300-my poor friend . [She]2300-my poor friend is of a good height , [her]2300-my poor friend voice is deep and manly ; moreover , remember , [she]2300-my poor friend and [Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp are [cousins]2302-cousins , and there is a distinct resemblance between [them]2302-cousins , especially in [their]2302-cousins gait and bearing . " [I]0-i am still a little fogged as to how exactly the bromide business was done , "[0-i] [I]0-i remarked .

" _ Bon ! _ [I]31-poirot will reconstruct for [you]2300-my poor friend as far as possible . [I]31-poirot am inclined to think that [Miss Howard]40-miss howard was [the master mind in that affair]2304-the master mind in that affair . [You]2300-my poor friend remember [her]2300-my poor friend once mentioning that [[her]2300-my poor friend father]2305-her father was [a doctor]157-a doctor ? Possibly [she]2300-my poor friend dispensed [his]2305-her father medicines for [him]2305-her father , or [she]2300-my poor friend may have taken the idea from one of the many books lying about when [Mademoiselle Cynthia]38-cynthia was studying for [her]38-cynthia exam . Anyway , [she]2300-my poor friend was familiar with the fact that the addition of a bromide to a mixture containing strychnine would cause the precipitation of the latter . Probably the idea came to [her]2300-my poor friend quite suddenly . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp had a box of bromide powders , which [she]44-mrs. inglethorp occasionally took at night . What could be easier than quietly to dissolve one or more of those powders in [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp 's large sized bottle of medicine when it came from [Coot]88-coot 's ? The risk is practically nil . The tragedy will not take place until nearly a fortnight later . If [anyone]1030-anyone has seen either of [them]2308-they touching the medicine , [they]1030-anyone will have forgotten it by that time . [Miss Howard]40-miss howard will have engineered [her]2300-my poor friend quarrel , and departed from [the house]1063-the house . The lapse of time , and [her]2300-my poor friend absence , will defeat all suspicion . Yes , it was a clever idea ! If [they]2308-they had left it alone , it is possible the crime might never have been brought [home]132-home to [them]2308-they . But [they]2308-they were not satisfied . [They]2308-they tried to be too clever and that was [their]2308-they undoing . "[31-poirot]

[Poirot]31-poirot puffed at [his]31-poirot tiny cigarette , [his]31-poirot eyes fixed on the ceiling .

" [They]2308-they arranged a plan to throw suspicion on [John Cavendish]32-john , by buying strychnine at [the village chemist 's]1696-the village chemist 's , and signing the register in [his]32-john hand - writing .[31-poirot]

" On Monday [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp will take the last dose of [her]44-mrs. inglethorp medicine . " But , as it will never do if [John]32-john , too , can prove an alibi , [she]44-mrs. inglethorp writes [him]37-mr. inglethorp an anonymous note still copying [his]37-mr. inglethorp hand - writing which takes [him]37-mr. inglethorp to [a remote spot where it is exceedingly unlikely that [anyone]1030-anyone will see [him]37-mr. inglethorp]2316-a remote spot where it is exceedingly unlikely that anyone will see him .[31-poirot]

" So far , all goes well . [Miss Howard]40-miss howard goes back to [Middlingham]14-middlingham . [Alfred Inglethorp]37-mr. inglethorp returns to [Styles]4-styles . " But now a hitch occurs . [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp does not take [her]44-mrs. inglethorp medicine that night . And then [he]37-mr. inglethorp makes [his]37-mr. inglethorp slip .[31-poirot]

" [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp is out , and [he]37-mr. inglethorp sits down to write to [[his]37-mr. inglethorp accomplice]2319-his accomplice , who , [he]37-mr. inglethorp fears , may be in a panic at the non - success of [their]2320-their plan . It is probable that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp returned earlier than [he]37-mr. inglethorp expected . Caught in the act , and somewhat flurried [he]37-mr. inglethorp hastily shuts and locks [his]37-mr. inglethorp desk . [He]37-mr. inglethorp fears that if [he]37-mr. inglethorp remains in [the room]230-the room [he]37-mr. inglethorp may have to open it again , and that [Mrs. Inglethorp]44-mrs. inglethorp might catch sight of the letter before [he]37-mr. inglethorp could snatch it up .
